When I first walked into Per Diem, I was impressed by the large chandelier and the dark colors and dark wood throughout the interior. You get this feeling of an old world rustic appeal.

Our party was seated upstairs and again, the lighting and interior create a very mellow and quaint feel, almost spooky. We decided to share several dishes, notably among them were the Squid Ink Linguine, Filet Mignon and Lobster Fries and Steamed Mussels. The Squid Ink was at best average as was the Filet Mignon which was tender enough but not very distinguished in flavor. The Steamed Mussels were however excellent and recommended. 

Again, I was the DD(surprise, surprise) on this night but I heard the cocktails were solid. Our waitress was friendly enough and did a good job. All in all, I'm not bowled over by the quality of the food here so my rating is closer to 3.5 stars but this is worth a visit at least once.
author: Angela L.

description: I came here with some co-workers and made sure to reserve a table ahead of time. We came in right at 12pm and got sat down upstairs. The place is very cool and has an old school vibe to it. I've passed by this place several times and just never even noticed that the place is bigger than it looks like from the outside. We ordered the meatballs and then some hummus for an appetizer. They both were great. The meatballs were nice and tasty and had a good flavor to them. The hummus was great at well and tasted very fresh. I ordered the Royals Burger with fries which was great as well! The burger was nice and juicy and the fries were perfectly crisp. For desert I had the apple tart which was great with some salted caramel ice cream. This was a super solid spot with some great service and I would definitely come back on my own to try some more items off the menu!
author: James R.

description: The artisan cheese plate and drinks were absolutely fantastic here. They have a really cool make your own Manhattan menu that resulted in a delicious cocktail. The salmon entree took way too long to come out, and was a little dry. The ambiance, free dessert, and great drinks made up for the lacking entree.
author: Lyndy W.

description:
Unique, delicious combination of Italian food and fast food!

I am not the fan of musrooms but, they made me very yummy mushrooms, carrot, avocado, and caramelized onion sandwich. Tomato soup is unique in flavor but very very delicious.
author: Dhwani T.

description:
Great food, ambiance, decor, and anchor steam on tap.  

Bree and Arne are new best friends.  

Go here.
author: Josh J.

description:
Just a quick note to say we had a 12+ group dinner for my daughters birthday on Saturday 2/3...
Food was very good but service was just spectacular...especially the manager who was prepared for us and was SO accommodating with our balloons, flowers and happy birthday sign....I regret I do not remember his name.  
Our servers TOM and Lux were consummate hospitality pro's.Tom did everything possible to make our experience comfortable and fun.
I had no Idea what to expect of this place...and came away super happy.
We will be back....
author: Russell B.

description: A bit pricy however completely delicious. Great service, lovely ambiance, young professionals, I'll definitely go back again.
author: Ravit B.

description:
Great tasting food, but they were out of an appetizer when we dined. While it's unfortunate that they didn't have an appetizer we'd wanted, I'd still come back another time. 
Great environment and friendly staff too!
author: Jessica M.

description:
This is an A-OK type of place as far as the ambience goes. On a Thursday night, Happy Hour is in full swing, and the place was mobbed with 20-and 30-somethings. My friend and I decided to stay anyway. We got a nice enough table, but the noise level was through the roof. It died down some as the most narcissistic, self-indulgent, overtly loud, self-consciously ostentatious kids began to leave. This place is better at weekend lunch if you're a more...ahem...seasoned patron.

Now for the food. We both had the salmon (I paired mine with a Daily Trader) and the fish was cooked to absolute and unassailable perfection. It came with grilled asparagus and asparagus puree. You know, asparagus is not one of my favorite vegetables. That said, my plate looked like it had just come out of the dishwasher by the time the waiter came to collect our plates. Ha ha ha. The DT was also delicious. I might have tried another cocktail, but I was with a friend who didn't drink, so I kept myself to the one.

So, if you're 40+ and have had that college-atmosphere energy out of your system for a couple of decades, you may prefer the weekend daytime. Or it's possible that other weeknights are tamer. Where you sit may also make a difference to the loud chatter, screaming, besotted bellows, etc., if you're there to catch up with a friend. Please know that, as far as the cuisine and drinks are concerned, you cannot go wrong.  No indeed!
author: L.E. W.

description: Great happy hour. Arnie is the best bartender in the financial district. Always remembers my order, my name and grabs me a bar stool whenever he can. His back up Bree is pretty fantastic as well. Very friendly atmosphere and love grabbing a quick beverage on my way to the ghetto train.
author: Vicki S.

description: Came in yesterday for the third time. Was sad to see the menu had changed, then found out the executive chef had changed too. Some of my favorite items were no longer on the menu (french onion soup, braised short ribs) and what I did order was not as good (tri tip sandwich and fries). The previous executive chef was amazing, sad to see him go, I probably won't come back.
author: C M.

description:
Went into Per Diem on a weeknight with a girlfriend for drinks and a few snacks. We were able to find a couple open seats at the bar and were warmly greeted by Griffen/Gryffin (not sure how to spell it?) and Arnie who were bartending. The restaurant was pretty busy and the bartenders were definitely slinging drinks left and right for everyone, but they still had time to make sure we were taken care of right away. Big compliments to the entire staff for being kind and courteous throughout our stay.

I ordered a cucumber gimlet and my friend had a Golden Gate Spritz off of their cocktail menu, both of which were great! Saw someone order a Billionaire Bramble next to me and I had to add it to my "must order" list ; ) Solid selection of beers and other spirits which I'm excited to sift through during my next visits. As for food, we ordered the avocado toast, burrata tartine, margherita flatbread and fried artichoke hearts--YUM! Everything came out promptly and definitely satisfied our hunger pangs. 

Overall, I'm really pleased with Per Diem and glad that I came in for a good time! If you're looking for swift and sweet service, tasty bites and craft cocktails that pack a punch, this is the spot for you. Will definitely be back for more drinks and to try some dinner entrees! Steak and lobster, I'm looking at you.. *heart eyes*
author: Karlie C.

description:
Squid ink linguine was ok: it didn't have a lot of the squid ink flavor -- likely the noodles were made elsewhere? Overall the pastas had too much butter in them.

The chicken looked bland, but was actually very flavorful. Cocktails here were great.

The appetizers and sides stood out and were great which is maybe why we were a little disappointed with how the entrees turned out.
author: Thomas C.

description: The burrata appetiser was very well put together. The hint of salt in the sweet stuff was a nice touch. Had the homemade mushroom pasta but it was a bit over-cooked. Watery cream of mushroom sauce was interesting but not in a bad way.
author: Ryan L.

description: Food is good, price is Fidi. Somewhere I'd go to take clients for sure, not sure if I'd make it a personal spot on the regular. The portions are ok, definitely can get same quality and more at other places but for consistent quality across multiple types of food, not a bad choice.
author: Phillip T.

description: Great service, nice wine list and good food.
author: Andrew F.

description: The service was a little bit slow but other than that, it was a great experience. We had the hummus starter, a beet salad and some chicken and everything tasted great.
author: Angela P.

description: After you walk in and think you are in the wrong place due to a rustic, industrial but kind of run down décor - you settle in to the a focused menu that is French Bistro like.  The food and recipes are excellent - with large portions and terrific sauces and main ingredients.  The flavorful sauces, vegetables, pickled adders to sandwiches like pickled onion, root veggies, carrot or radish add a twang to a sweet, savory sauce that is hard to describe. Full bar and room upstairs as well.
author: Ted D.

description:
The duck burrata catastrophe salad needs to be taken off the menu if it hasn't been already. 

Like the shows where the chef's like naw man this ain't gonna work and spits the bite out, except I'm not a chef and my friend from is sitting in front me talking about serious stuff so I'm chewing silently. 

Still mustering up courage to go back.
author: Josephine L.

description:
We came here for dinner on a weeknight. The first floor is very crowded during happy hour, but luckily we had made a reservation and the upstairs is quieter and quite romantic/chic for dinner. 

I'm definitely a cocktails person and wished that they had a bit more variety in their cocktail menu. I ended up doing the "Create your own Manhattan" where you choose your own bourbon/rye, vermouth and bitter. I had no idea what I was choosing really, but it was fun to read the flavor descriptions and pretend I was a bad-ass who knew my bourbons.

The food was pretty good. I had the soup of the day which was a tortilla soup which was very well-flavored and stocked with vegetables and beans. Their main dishes are $20-30 bucks which didn't look appealing enough to me for the price. 
Our server was mia during most of the evening.
author: Sharon H.

description: Love their interior decoration, our waitress was extremely courteous. However the portion is very small for the price they charge. I ordered short rib, it was drier than it supposed to be, same situation with the fries. If they cut the fries not as thin, it might solve the problem.
author: Jason W.

description: Very cool place tucked away...gotta look for this place...a little hidden as far as street signs but very hip atmosphere and decor was awesome. Drinks were a little too strong but just get a beer or wine off of a great menu and food was solid....healthy and tasty. Would totally recommend!
author: Katie N.

description:
Great little place for happy hour after work! Lots of seating/bar/standing room. You have to try the tartine burratta. It's to die for. Creamy burratta on top of a crusty toast with marcona almonds and a light honey drizzle.

Was sad though that they have a TV that doesn't play any sports.
author: Julia M.

description:
I don't even remember bookmarking this place, but somehow it's on my list of places to try near where I worked.  I had plans to go see a show later that night, and I've had some long weeks at work, so I decided to treat myself. 

I came by looking for a table, but it was packed with groups of people who looked like they just got off work, but since I was really nice and polite to the host, I definitely was able to get a table. I only needed it for like an hour since I had to get to my play. 

Ordered a glass of prosecco (since I've been trying to lose weight) I haven't really been drinking and it was delicious. I also ordered the squid ink pasta with shrimp and scallops. I've been on this scallop craving for a while. It was a little strange with pasta with cream, but it was good.  I do like cream, but the issue is seafood and cream isnt always the best. 

Service was great! Host, waiter, overall, it was wonderful! 

Protip: Get some drinks and food and have a good time!
author: Nina Y.

description: I may be biased because I know and like one of the partners here, but I think Per Diem is a FiDi standout. It's a cozy, good looking space and the service was cordial and attentive. The cocktails were average to just above average, but the food is where they excel -- truly tasty.
author: Bobby N.

description: Went for Lunch, the sandwiches were incredible! A little pricey, but the food is quality and the restaurant itself It very cute and has a nice ambiance. It's great that it's in downtown, but not in an extremely overcrowded area. I will go back when I visit SF again.
author: Calvin S.

description: Outstanding food and service. Perfect temp on the burger, nice wine selection and prompt service.
author: T S.

description: Pasta was incredible came for dinner after a hh in the hood and the French onion soup yum yum
author: Morgan S.

description: Interior is adorable; menu is delicious. Steak & lobster is very reasonably priced and they were super flexible with my substitutions since I was extra high maintenance due to being on Whole 30 at the time.  Lots of gluten-free options as well. Been here twice already within a month and will definitely be back soon.
author: Kristina I.

description:
I attended a business lunch here and I really liked the decor and the ambiance of the restaurant. We were seated upstairs and our waitress was very friendly. We ordered the following and everything was delicious. 
Tempura Asparagus, Trufe Mushroom and Steak au Poivre. Wish we coud have tired the desert  but we were pressed on time. I definetly want to come back and try other entree options.
author: Irma R.

description: My husband and I had our wedding reception at Per Diem after our City Hall wedding, and are so happy we did! We appreciated that Per Diem doesn't charge a room rental fee for private events, and that at every step of the way Emily (Event Coordinator) was extremely helpful, friendly and accommodating. All our guests raved about the atmosphere of the restaurant as well as the food and wine. If you're looking for a great location for a private party or just a great meal, I highly recommend Per Diem!
author: Allison D.

description: Let me tell you....this was a hidden gem!!!  We had a horrible day with some travel difficulties and were upset and discouraged and just wanted to find a wonderful meal which until this establishment, seemed impossible with all the restaurants in the SF area we tried during our stay that were (to say the least) average and disappointing.  We walked in late and were one of a very few people which was fine with us on this night.  This was more of a lounge look that we are not used to.  The woman that ended up serving us was very friendly and accommodating.  She misunderstood what I ordered and thought we wanted to share a steak and lobster meal but we did not want that and she was more than accommodating to make up for this error.  Let me tell you..... it was actually just enough for the two of us.  The Filet Mignon was done perfectly, the lobster was tender and melted in your mouth.  The presentation was lovely.  She offered a complimentary dessert which was unnecessary and much appreciated.  We ordered the key lime tart and the chocolate mousse desert and did not expect this to be comped which she did comp both.  These desserts were the best we had had in a very long time. We are from NYC and have dined at the best of the best and this out shined many of them.  It was just what we needed and made our night.  My only regret was that we found it literally right before we left or would have been back several more times during our stay.  I highly recommend this establishment and will never think wonderful food only comes with white tablecloths again!  Thank you for our wonderful meal and turning our night around!
author: Dawn Q.

description: Cute and cozy place. Went with a couple friends for lunch but also saw some people there for business meals. Tried a few appetizers and the mushroom pasta, all taste delicious. Recommended!
author: Cathy S.

description:
A classic restaurant hiding in the financial district. It may look small from the entrance, but it's spacious and two-story inside. 
For starter, my friend and I had charcuterie and cheese board - the quality is good but I wish the waitress can introduce the plate for us. 
For main dishes, we ordered a squid ink linguini and chicken burrata flat bread - I really enjoyed the flat break which is soft, with a right amount of tomato sauce and burrata cheese, and tendered chicken chunks! The linguini is a bit too soft but it came with a generous amount of scallop and shrimps which were seasoned well.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Don't know what I was expecting, but it was good food at a fair price but nothing exciting.  
We had a couple salads and they were as described.  I had the Waldorf and it was too tart for my taste.  Didn't finish it.  
Ask for bread and water for it to be served.  
The avocado toast is exactly that.  Something my daughter makes at home daily for her breakfast or lunch. 
The portions for entrees were on the modest size, but it was enough.  I had the squid ink pasta, and though beautifully colored, it was not very flavorful.  I couldn't even tell what kind of sauce it wks.  The scallops and prawns were perfectly cooked though.   
Service was decent, but not attentive.  We had to ask for water, the bill and for him to pick up the bill and process it bc we had theater tickets.
author: Berles C.

description:
Would totally have given this place 1 star if it wasn't for how the manager/waitress who made the end of our stay better than the start. Our party had a reservation for 5:30pm in which they called to confirm the same day. We arrived 17 minutes after our reservation and apparently they give away tables after 15 minutes without notice (just TWO minutes). We were pretty unhappy, especially since the guy with a man bun who we checked in with kept giving us attitude...that guy was not accommodating at all.

We ended up sticking around to grab drinks at the bar and left our name down to waitlist for the next open table. We were promised a table so the waitress took our order ahead of time and then unfortunately made a mistake about the availability of that open table. Thus we had to wait just a bit longer. Not the best start am I right? 

The drinks were nice though, I got a Teely Peach which tasted like refreshing champaign served at weddings. Eventually we did get a table and the food came right out since we had ordered ahead. We got oysters, cheese boards, patte, and truffle mushroom arugula pizza. I would say the food was alright. The manager ended up coming out to apologize to us about our experience. He told our waitress who was darling I have to admit to bring us 2 order of fries with lobster bits on the house. That was actually my favorite order of the night. Overall definitely applaud their efforts to make it up to us.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Went to Per Diem after yoga class and loved it! Devin greeted me at the front and he was hella chill. The cheeseburger was super tasty! Monica the bartender made me an amazing vodka tonic with a lime wedge. She was also hella chill! The beautiful manager Anna was so nice and sweet. She told me some hilarious knock knock jokes! I was cracking up! I wanted to stay longer because I was having so much fun, but I had to take off for my spin class...
The chieftain Irish pub used to be my go to place to eat and drink but now Per Diem is! I hella love this place!
author: Daniel M.

description: Horrible portion for the price . Quality of food was so bleh. Cauliflower tasted like boiled cauliflower
author: Sanjeeda N.

description:
I suppose Per Diem is owed a review, given the numerous times I've been here now (including the times I don't entirely remember anymore either). But, much like Garaje was a Klout favorite, Per Diem is a Lithium favorite: in fact, I've yet to come here without coworkers! I've also yet to ever spend my own money, but that's a different matter.

The alcohol is pretty solid, so I'll just leave it at that. The food though? Mixed, ranging from okay, to pretty damn delicious. So, come here, grab some drinks, make sure to order the right dishes, and you'll leave content!

So, what's good, or even great, here? Going from appetizers to mains: their happy hour cheese board, the burrata and honey on bread, the pork belly roulade (which seemed more like an entree than an appetizer), and the duck breast.

How about the rest? Well, the brussels sprouts are tasty, but a bit too sweet; the flatbread changes up every so often and isn't bad; the oysters are too briny for my tastes; the swordfish has great flavor, but is on the dry side; and the lamb is also just okay.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A fairly large space, but with limited accessible seating: Their upstairs isn't accessible, and much of the downstairs consists of bar seating, high tops, or booths. I don't recall what the back of the restaurant looks like, but there are about four or five tables up front that are actually accessible.

Bathroom - Didn't try them (or, at least, I don't remember trying them).
author: Johnny W.

description: This place is hot garbage. Went as a small group and they forgot my order. More on that later. Service was slow but friendly and the decor was fine, if a bit confusing at parts (we sat facing a raised, empty small room with tables and chairs). The menu is small and unappetizing. A good portion of the dishes seemed like cheap and simple offerings at inflated prices like hummus or avocado toast, which were fine at best, for dishes I could make with the current contents of my pantry for free. The hummus came with matzah crackers, which were pretty decent. Water and bread aren't available unless you ask, which is offputting. My friend ordered a drink with the opening round of drink orders and then no one was around to check on a refill for most of our time there so he had a total of two drinks the whole night instead of the 3-5 he typically orders. When they brought out the food, they put my side in front of my friend (easy mistake) and never brought my food. Whoever brought out the food either didn't notice the empty table in front of me or thought that was fine because when they had completed setting it all down they left without saying 'you're getting food too' or anything. We had to work out that they had forgot my entree order. I had the Brussels sprouts as a side which they graciously didn't forget, and they were bad. They had some mild char on them but they were just gross boiled Brussels sprouts, no culinary artistry or style, just boiled soggy sprouts with some bacon bits (which were good to be fair). They were disappointing. Speaking of disappointing, when they brought my entree, which arrived as they were clearing the plates from everyone else at the table, I was ready to eat, but when I tried the pasta I wished they had just forgotten it. The pasta tasted like dirty water. I dunno how else to put it. Wet, watery, some impurities, the slightest hint of egg, and nothing else. The mushrooms were fine, I ate all of them because they had flavor, but the pasta tasted as if it were merely wet noodles. I'm sure everyone has ups and downs but even giving them a lot more credit than I feel they deserve results in a quintessentially underwhelming experience. Sorry Per Diem. One thing I will say is that their prices seem pretty reasonable, most of the entrees topped out at under 30 dollars, but I'd rather spend 36 dollars on a 20 dollar pasta than spend 20 dollars for dirty water pasta. Sorry guys. Maybe their lunch is better?
author: Spencer C.

description:
I came here with my co-workers for lunch after an outing in the city and we really enjoyed the food! It's a bit $$, but the service was excellent and the quality of the food was great. They also have some very good alcoholic drinks.

We ordered the garlic chicken + mushroom flatbreads, charcuterie board, and fries to share. Everything was tasty. For entree I ordered the petrale sole fish, was came with a creamy sauce. I enjoyed it very much.

Others on my team ordered the steak, croque madam, and mushroom pasta. I think the steak seemed to be the best dish. It was a huge piece of meat and perfectly cooked. 

For dessert we ordered the apple tart and passion fruit mousse to share. Both were very good. By checking in to Yelp, we also received complimentary tea or coffee, which was nice. Solid 4 stars and definitely worth a return visit.
author: Sophia H.

description: We went here on a late Friday afternoon, the upstairs was closed so we sat at the bar.  Delicious cocktails!  I had the nicoise salad which i thought was lacking some flavor. I asked for some capers, which they brought right away. They were slightly crispy capers and were a perfect addition to the salad. My husband had the tri tip sandwhich which was served on amazing crusty bread. The meat was delicious, a great thing to order.  We will definitely be back when in the neighborhood
author: Taylor T.

description: Visited at dinner time for group event. The food wasn't terrible, but it just didn't strike me as delicious, and for sure it didn't "wow" me. I get that our menu was limited because it was such a large party (the top floor was reserved for just us), but for just being a 3-course meal with 3 options for dinner, the service was slow, and the food was mediocre. Our dinner course wasn't served until almost 10pm, and we started at 7pm. We didn't have any speeches or activities, it was JUST a dinner. The ambience and decor were great, so I expected more for a San Francisco restaurant in the heart of downtown. I feel there are too many SF restaurants to choose from for me to return to this one.
author: Irene B.

description: My team hosted a happy hour at Per Diem on Monday night, and we couldn't have been more thrilled with the vibe of the restaurant, the attentive staff, and of course, the cocktails.  We'd book with them again in a heartbeat!
author: Rachel G.

description:
We came for dinner on a Wednesday. Parking was fairly easy, but driving in that area is hectic. It took about 15 minutes to move 1 block. There must've been construction or something. It's close to Bart, so I would recommend that option. 

The decor is wonderful. It's kind of a vintage ship wreck library feel. 

Our table ordered the Burrata Tartine, Avocado Toast and pickles as an appetizer. All were delicious. The tartine and toast were a decent portion for 2-3 people to share. We had 4 people and there was definitely a couple of "no, it's okay--you have it" moments. I think I'll order the burrata for dinner next time. 

I ordered the wild mushroom pasta as my entree. It was tasty, but for the portion size and being $20 I won't order it again. 

After our plates were taken away, we were kind of forgotten and had to ask about water refills. At one point my friend got up to get the carafe from the bar. The restaurant wasn't busy, so we didn't see the harm in catching up with our friends. I love that sf is conserving water, but if tiny water cups are used, a craft to refill yourself is nice to have. 

Overall, it was lovely restaurant. And I'll be back for the burrata.
author: Jenny C.

description: Had the Burrata Margarita Flatbread and the Roasted Tomato Soup... It was DELICIOUS! This place looks a little fancy, but it is very casual. The staff was very prompt and polite. I highly recommend giving this place a try! You won't be disappointed!
author: Jill F.

description: Emily and Bri are amazing. I booked an event here and they made my life so easy. Everyone loved it and it was amazing
author: Michael N.

description: Amazing, cute, hip, trendy bar in the financial district. Everything we got was amazing. The decor in the bar is super cute and takes you back in time. The atmosphere was great. The food was also equally as delicious. The avocado toast and steak are a definite must. The cocktails are also spot on. Would definitely recommend to anyone who is around that area, but make sure to make reservations for dinner if you don't want to sit at the bar.
author: Sofia V.

description:
Great food, good service, and elegant decor - a solid dinner spot.

My friends and I shared the roasted Brussels sprouts and mushroom flatbread as starters - both were good.  I got the wild mushroom pasta as my main, and quite enjoyed it.  I also had a bit of my friend's beet salad, which was delicious.  Our group of 4 shared the 3 layered chocolate mousse for dessert - it pretty good.  I also enjoyed my Citrus Trade cocktail.

The service was friendly, patient, and prompt - I was quite pleased.

We were seated upstairs, and loved the old-school library feel of the dining room.

Overall, we had a great experience here!
author: Barnali D.

description:
How did I not know about this gem a stone's throw away from the Montgomery Bart station.  Per Diem, you rock.

Met 2 of my girlfriends here for a long overdue catch up drinks/dinner sess on Wednesday and it was the perfect spot, suggested by my friend Miss M.  She works in FiDi so she knows all the spots the cool kids hang out.  I used to be one of those cool kids.  Now I spend most of my evenings picking up dog poop and chasing after my little devil of a puppy.  

Upon arriving at Per Diem, I was drawn in by the dark, rusty decor and intimate atmosphere.  This place is perfect for a hideaway, a romantic date or a place to relax after working hard all day.  I instantly felt much better after stepping in and seeing my gorgeous friend's big smile as she sat at the bar.

My cocktail was called Bimbo, which we had a good laugh over.  It is a great summer drink.  Vodka, grapefruit liquor and lime.  Refreshing and tasty, I recommend it!

Appetizers included the holy moly delicious fresh burrata on thin toasted bread, drizzled with honey and almonds.  It was a tasty pillow of fabuloso in my mouth.  The mussels were good but soooo tiny and such a small portion, I would not recommend it.  Not worth for the price.

For the main entree, I ordered the beef short rib tagliatelle with roasted red bell peppers.  This dish was absolutely melt in your mouth fantastic.  The sauce was perfect, not too salty and savory enough to keep you wanting more.  I also had a small taste of my friend's flat bread (with arugula and cheese, yum!).  The other friend ordered pork chops.  It looked moist and perfectly cooked.  I did not try any because of my pork allergy.

We were there for 2 hours, eating, laughing, bonding over boy troubles and life troubles.  Drowning our sorrows in delicious cocktails and carb heaven.  This is definitely a place I would return to.  Good work, Per Diem.
author: Yue L.

description: I had a flatbread of some sort for lunch. The crust was pretty hard and the flavors were forgettable.  The service was so so too. Seems like one of those overhyped SF restaurants that I am not returning to again.
author: T S.

description:
Service was not bad, just okay. We had the seat at the corner by the window which was really cool cus it felt like we were sitting outside! The interior of the restaurant was absolutely amazing!!! 

We had ordered charcuterie- pretty good! Selection of cheese was really good. Some really salty meats though...

Duck pâté- absolutely the best!!! My favorite thing I had here! 

We both had ordered drinks (old fashion and tom collins) and it seemed to be more watery than usual.
author: Crystal W.

description:
We were looking for a place near the Palace Hotel on a Saturday night to have a quick but lovely supper before heading out to see Hamilton at the Orpheum. 

The walk to Per Diem was nice -- we didn't see too many vagrants which can be the case in the City.  We were slightly delayed at the hotel which required us to accelerate our dining plan. We arrived just before 7:00 and were seated promptly. We let the hostess know we had theater tickets. Our server brought water and reassured us that he was aware of our tight schedule, we ordered steak and lobster. I had the thyme cocktail which was absolutely amazing. Not too sweet and very refreshing. The food came in about 20 Minutes. Oh.my.gosh. It was to die for. I think that must be the best filet I've ever had in recent memory! We also ordered a side of green beans almondine. Cooked to perfection! There was nothing on our plates that we did not like. The presentation was beautiful. The potatoes were scrumptious and portions were just right for which I was grateful. I don't like to waste, but I also didn't relish being overfull during the show. We finished our meal and settled the bill by about 7:40, called for a Lyft and made it to the theater and into our seats well before the start of the show.

Wonderful, beautiful, delicious and intimate yet casual experience!
author: Melissa L.

description: Just gotta say that the salmon nicoise salad ($16) is a surprisingly good salad. Not sure why I was surprised, now that I think about it. But the surprise worked in my favor since low or no expectations make everything better. The salmon was perfect. Not dry at all, seasoned well. The lettuce was somehow some of the best I've had in a salad. Even the half an egg was better than expected. Perhaps if I did have to choose one element that was lacking, it was the green beans, and only because they were very plain compared to everything else. OK that seems like enough of a ramble on a salad...for now...
author: Andrew R.

description:
I went here for a birthday dinner with my friends on a Friday night. They recently got a new head chef so the menu is different from what is on Yelp. Lots of the food you see in these photos are no longer being served. I would check Per Diem's website for the most updated menu.

It was our first time at this restaurant and everything was delicious! We started off with the Smoked Bacon Tarte Flambee. This is a THIN flat bread shaped like a pizza. It was good, but the bread was so thin, it was almost like eating air. The Tarte Flambee will do nothing to help you satisfy your hunger. I recommend skipping on this appetizer.

For my entree, I had the Pasta de la Min, and it was one of the best pastas I've ever had! The mushrooms, truffle sauce, and duck egg all blended very nicely, and despite not containing any meat, it was very flavorful. My only complaint about this dish was that it was not filling enough. The portions at this restaurant are pretty small, and one dish won't fill you up, unless you want to break the bank.

I also had a bite of my friend's dish (Filet Mignon et Frites aux Homard) and it was delicious! The steak was flavorful, not too chewy, and my friend could not stop praising the lobster fries.

We finished dinner off with some mango cake and a salted caramel pie with ice cream (sorry, can't remember the names). Both were good, but the pie was better.

Overall, I really enjoyed this restaurant and the food, despite the small portions. I told them it was my birthday in my reservation, but they didn't provide any sort of complimentary birthday dessert, just an FYI.

Food: Delicious!
Price range: PRICEY! $20-$40+ per person
Service: Great! Our waitress was attentive and friendly
Decor: We sat upstairs where the decor was library-themed. Intimate and cozy!
Ambiance: Semi-dressy, classy
Sound: Moderate, it's louder downstairs where the bar is
author: Maranda C.

description:
I had a business lunch here recently.  Overall, the service was good, as was the food.  However, the setting was difficult for this lunch, as the table - and several others - were located near the door (in a heavy-traffic area).  As a result, it was noisy and distracting.

Overall, the meal was fine - just would have preferred a better environment for talking.
author: Brian O.

description:
We had a reservation, so we were seated in their cozy upstairs area - nice wooden tables to add to the restaurant's entire rustic decor. The maitre d' and our server were both extremely friendly and made us feel very welcome - our server was energetic throughout the meal and started the ball rolling on a great dining experience. 

FOOD: 
- Cheese board/Salumi board: Both delicious with a decent amount of food on each - the pate on the salumi board was especially good. 
- Flatbread: Easy appetizer to share with a group of people! Small enough that you are satisfied while you're waiting for your food, but not too much! 
- Cioppino: Was feeling in a seafood mood, and I wasn't disappointed! The tomato saffron broth was delicious and creamy - my only complaint is that the portion, though it seemed large, was actually a bit small. 
- Lemon tart: YUM. It was just the right amount of sweet and tangy and was a decently sized slice! 
- Chocolate pot de creme type thing: I expected it to be slightly larger, so this is definitely not a sharing dessert. Sometimes restaurants can make chocolate desserts way too sweet, but Per Diem got this one right! 

Overall, I'll definitely be back! We didn't have to wait very long for our food, and our server was very attentive the entire time. Just wished the portions would be a little bit larger.
author: Sophie H.

description: The food was okay , but the portions were really small  for the price of dinner. Don't know about the bar part though
author: Rachael H.

description: This place is great.  I haven't tried any dinner here yet.  But the lunch burger and tri tip sandwich is great.  Ordered the burger royale medium rare and it's delicious.   Although tried my buddy's tri-tip sandwich. yummy!
author: Paul T.

description:
This place ended up being a lot better than I expected. Working in FiDi, a lot of these restaurants start to feel really similar, but Per Diem is definitely a must try.  I came here on a Wednesday evening with my little sister right after I got off work. We got here around 5:20 ish and immediately got seated at the bar.

Food: We ordered the muscles and the squid ink linguini. The muscles tastes like they usually taste, but the linguini definitely stole the show. It was light and buttery, the scallops and shrimp were cooked perfectly. Amazing all around. We also ordered the creme Burke for dessert which I think would've tasted better if the top glaze was just slightly more crunchy.

Drinks: We started off with a couple of cocktails and ended with some sparkling rose. They were all delicious.

Service: Amazing. We sat at the bar and our server/bartender was really friendly and was always there when we needed him but was not too in the way of our conversation.

The only negative is that it's a teensy bit loud, but that's pretty typical for a happy hour spot in SF. Overall, great food, drinks, and atmosphere.
author: Teresa N.

description: Everything is great except that waitress checkes in every 20 minutes while you're enjoying conversation with your friend. Squid ink linguini and house special hummus are outstandingly amazing.
author: Nancy W.

description:
Excellent comfort food in a quirky well decorated spot. I got a table upstairs in the "library" and it was super cozy.

I was *that* person in a restaurant who pulled out her laptop because of a work emergency. The staff were understanding and kind... I do feel bad thanks for not making me feel any worse. 

In my opinion this is one of the best mid-range places to eat in FiDi.
author: Sylvia W.

description:
Great little bar close to my office in the financial district. Everything I look for in a happy hour spot can be found at Per Diem... Atmosphere, service, drink selection (Bullet Bourbon and Racer IPAs are my go-to drinks) and a nice professional crowd.

Don't bitch about the prices. It's the area. The crowd. The vibe. Great service. 

Drink up. Tip well. Enjoy. Cheers!
author: Mike P.

description:
I came here for a business lunch and ordered the shrimp Louie salad. Thoughts:

Pros:
-Marinated shrimp was delicious and flavorful
-Vegetables were fresh and seasoned with a dash of pepper
-Complimentary bread as a starter with butter

Cons:
-Menu is very, very limited at lunch
-I got about 3.5 shrimps total. For a shrimp salad, that's just pathetic

If my meal hadn't been paid for, I probably would not have come at all due to such small portions.
author: Patricia Z.

description: The service was excellent even though it was quite busy for a Wednesday at 6:30. Sat at the bar, ordered the Cava - Spanish sparkling wine & the tomato soup (w/o bread or cheese or extras). It was more than satisfactory! The tomato soup had great flavor. It was homemade & you could taste the love. The bartender was attentive, yet, not annoying. Didn't feel rushed & felt like I could relax at the end of my day. The overall ambiance was pleasant. Try the tomato soup!
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
I would recommend this place for chilling with friends by the bar after work. It's nice inside (there's an upstairs), and this place usually gets filled with people who work nearby in Financial District / SoMa.

The best food I had here was the burrata served on bread sprinkled with honey? almonds? SO YUM. I would definitely come back for that and drinks.

The rest of the food I tried here were just mediocre at best: 
- Flatbread: are there multiple flatbreads offered here? Not sure, but the one I had was okay.
- Cheese board: one of my coworkers lovessssss the cheeseboard, but I think it's okay haha. I'm just the type that would prefer to have more of one thing I like (rather than an assortment)
- some pork belly happy hour item
- some lamb item
- duck breast
- brussel sprouts
- oysters
- swordfish
author: Annie S.

description:
Came for a business lunch and shit hit the fan pretty fast (excuse the language).

Walked in, seated promptly b/c we had a reservation and was given menus. Our waitress came over to take our orders, everyone was ready except me so she asked if we wanted more time. We said no b/c everyone could order first while I picked but that got her super confused. She finally understood that we could order and then started to take orders. 

We sat for about 40 min and our food was not even here. No bread, no food, nothing. My boss checked in with her about the food and she apologized and said it was on its way. Finally after about 50 min of waiting, our orders came out and the waiter had no clue whose dish was whose. He was putting the wrong dishes in front of each person and it was such a mess. Our fries we ordered to start our meal off with ended up coming last too. No bread still, even though other tables had it.

My boss ordered a caesar salad with chicken added, which ended up coming with no chicken, which she was obviously not happy about. I had the shrimp louie salad which was not bad but I frankly have no clue why a salad took them 50 min to make. 

The slowness of the food really effected the business lunch and distinguished the place as NOT being the right place to do business at. The waitress apologized so much and took 20% off our meal I believe, which was really kind of her but to be honest, for the price you're paying for the restaurant, service should be on point and it really wasn't.

Probably won't be back here unless it's with my bf (possibly) but my boss and our team for sure will NOT be back for another business lunch. ever.
author: Cynthia H.

description: Super friendly services. My friend and I went in on a busy Friday night but we manage to get a couple of open seat at the bar. Food was unexpectedly great! I'd for sure come back here during my next visit to SF.
author: Sze Wa C.

description:
Really cute place. Came here for lunch with a few friends, we made reservations.

Tri Tip Sandwich was really good. The bread was really toasty and thick enough to hold all the filling. Tender slices of tri tip and lots of melty cheese. My friend thought it was too sweet because of the caramelized red onions, but I loved it.

French Onion soup was average, but still very good.

Would come back if I am in the area. Parking was a pain, but expected.
author: Erica L.

description:
Today was my 4th time to Per Diem for an office lunch.  I've always come with a reservation, and have always been seated pretty shortly after arrival. Per Diem seems pretty full around lunchtime, and reservations do run out quickly so I would advise getting your table reserved to avoid the wait. They have plenty of tables to accommodate both large and small groups. 

I love the atmosphere and decor here at Per Diem. It's a great hidden gem amidst the many nearby grab and go lunch places. Service is amazing as well.

They've recently changed their lunch menu. It no longer includes their Cioppino, and the Roast Chicken is listed differently from before. I'm a bit sad to see those options gone, but my coworkers and I had the Petrale Sole Fillet and the Grilled Steak and really enjoyed our meals. The sole was served with a duo of leeks and a sweet potato mash which both paired so well with the fish. The serving size could be bigger when compared to how much food my coworkers received with their steak entrees, but I didn't leave hungry so I guess no change is actually needed. 

After our entree, we did go for some dessert. We ordered the chocolate mousse cake and the apple tourte with the salted caramel gelato. The chocolate dessert was very decadent and extremely chocolate-y. It wasn't too sweet as it included dark chocolate which was a delight. However, the apple tourte stole the show. It was light, crispy, and flaky. Every bite was divine. The salted caramel gelato was the perfect pairing. I would come back for this dessert any day.
author: Nancy T.

description: Solid cocktails. Overall solid food across the board. I don't love the ambiance, but found the service to be warm.
author: Amjad S.

description:
Chicken burrata flatbread to start. It was okay

Hubby ordered the filet & lobster fries. Filet was cooked perfectly. Lobster fries were kinda weird. It's French fries with lobster chunks marinated together. 

I had the wild mushroom truffle pasta & added chicken. Gross!!! The chicken was tiny over cooked pieces that were tough to chew!
author: Veronica K.

description:
Folks, I will tell you right now: when you visit Per Diem, try a Manhattan. They have a "make your own" option, and in my experience, the wait staff are happy to help you choose the perfect combination. I had the Whistle Pig rye, Cocchi di Torino vermouth, and orange bitters, and oh my goodness it was delicious. 

In addition to this, we had the mushroom pasta (homemade tagliatelle), tasty French onion soup, and very well prepared seasonal roast vegetables. 

Nice atmosphere - slightly quirky but not pretentious, and great music choices creating a nice ambience. 

Very happy with our choice all around, and looking forward to visiting here again next time we're in the City!
author: Hollis M.

description: Went here with a girlfriend for happy hour and did not disappoint! We made reservations at 5:15pm, and was taken to the 2nd floor. When asking for the happy hour menu, we were told we needed to be downstairs for that. So downstairs we went and lucky for us we spotted the last small table for 2. Took a bit for the waitress to come by and help us out, but understandable since it was busy. We ordered the HH special wine - 2 glasses of house Syrah ($6/glass), the mussels, fries, and the burrata flatbread. The wine did not disappoint. The mussels meat were kinda small and disappointing, but it tasted great! Nothing special about the fries (we didn't order the garlic fries), but liked that it came w/ ketchup and mayo. And the burrata margarita flatbread was delicious!! Definitely recommend the flatbread!! Next time when looking for a HH spot in FiDi, def recommend trying out Per Diem!
author: Em K.

description: Food, drinks, and atmosphere were great! Food was also at a decent price. The only complaint was the waiter. We sat upstairs and our waiter never once asked how our food was.
author: Levi D.

description:
Started with the MXN. Good, but the strawberry and jalapeno flavors were quite light. I recall even tasting the strawberry... 

Moved onto the buratta. Delicious, with a nice honey drizzle! but it's hard to go wrong with that. 

For my main, had the wild mushroom pasta. The tagliatelle was clearly homemade and fresh, and cooked perfectly. The sauce was perfectly balanced and flavored and had a rich creaminess. 

If only I had known that the bread was on request... :( The place is dimly lit so I didn't see that small squiggly note at the bottom until just now.
author: Dimple B.

description: My co-workers and I love this place. Whether it is for lunch, dinner or company hours, Per Diem is the first place that comes to our mind. They have great cocktails and small appetizers for sharing. Whenever we have our company happy hours, we order the brussels sprouts and flatbread. The dinner menu is amazing also! I had their lamb and my friend had rabbit and really enjoyed the food and service.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Great spot for work lunches (or dinners) in FiDi. Also, takes reservations here on Yelp which is helpful. 

Had the vegetarian wild mushroom pasta w mushroom foam and it was delicious ($20). Really well cooked. 

The French fries and service are excellent as well. I'd come back.
author: Chuck N.

description: Love the tri-tip sandwich. Love the interior decorations! The service could have been a bit faster (i think the 2nd flr during lunch is a bit understaffed) but our waitress was amazing!
author: Sally W.

description:
Open table suggested this restaurant to me. I raised a skeptical eyebrow after trying to book a table for us and another couple without avail. So I called them. They were very accommodating and my hopes were high! Per Diem did not disappoint. 1. The atmosphere was phenomenal and the decor was beautiful and warm. 2. The menu options were delightful and delicious and expertly presented (I had the beet salad and the pork belly). 3. The wine list was thorough. 4. The dining music was super (Pandora's INXS) 6. The service was outstanding - not obsequious but not rude either and very knowledgable. 

I truly enjoyed this dining experience. I will suggest Per Diem to my chef and foodie friends and I'll return to the restaurant soon.
author: Gwen S.

description: I tried to go to this place 2x for happy hour and it was always pack before 5pm with a 30 min wait. Finally, I decided to drop by for lunch. Made reservations and was seated promptly. Their appetizers menu was lacking... I wanted something like grilled octopus or fried calamari. Anyways, the mussels were good. Which I was very impressed with. Their short rib was tender but not yummy. Service was okay since it was just one waiter.
author: Ann L.

description:
tldr: the ambience was great for an intimate dinner, and the food, recommendations, and service was fantastic.

After we were seated, our server Monica recommended the fantastic burrata (pairs well with a custom Manhattan), followed by mushroom and bacon flat bread and squid ink pasta. I had the Greenback somewhere in the middle, and then an old-fashioned Old Fashioned with some kind of caramel ice cream wonderland that our server recommended. I think it's my new go-to dinner place in fidi.
author: Jack L.

description: Had a wonderful dinner for a family celebration.  The food was excellent as was the service!
author: Denise A.

description: Rock solid food and old school ambiance make this a perfect off the beaten path for a business lunch.
author: Pete M.

description:
I'm going to start this review off by saying what I said to the waitress after I ate my chocolate creme brulee in under 5 minutes: YOUR DESSERTS ARE OFF THE HOOK. 

Yes, I totally needed to yell (cap) that, because almost every corner, every edge of those four stars is because of their desserts, and the rest of the credit goes to how beautiful this place is. It's basically my dream pirate boat, except as a restaurant in the financial district. I swear they have an art piece that is the inside hardware of a piano.

I came here on two separate occasions: once with coworkers with a party of 10, and another time at 5:30 pm on a Friday with my husband for a date. 

This is a great place for a coworker lunch. We got to pick from a few selections, and I think they actually offer great prices if it's a corporate lunch. I was in a rush this time, so I tried their flatbread app, and had the roast chicken. Everything was good. FYI, their iced tea is of a perfumey fruity variety if you're into that kind of thing.

As for the dinner, I am sad to report that it was underwhelming. My date ordered the risotto which was $18 of boring rice and even more boring vegetables. My swordfish was cooked well but under-seasoned, and whatever else was happening on my plate looked like the end of a very messy war between sea creatures and gross pasta washed up on a foamy shore. #grosspiratefood. I think there was some homemade orecchiette on my plate, but that was basically like the hippie-dip color-free playdoh Marin moms made when I was kid left out in the sun room overnight, turning it into dry, hard crusty rocks. I pretty much never complain about food, but I did this time because it was simply inedible. 

I'll come back for dessert and to coo over the decor.
author: Natasha P.

description:
We came here for happy hour with ten minutes to spare. We were quickly seated and asked if we wanted to order from the happy hour menu. We ordered and were told that we could have an additional 10 minutes to choose food items SCORE!

The waitress was pleasant & attentive, but didn't over do it.

We ordered the charcuterie cheese board, the truffle mushroom flatbread(recommended by the server) and the olive tapenade. All tasted perfect with our wine(6 glasses totalThe bill was around $120. 

We enjoyed it and will be back!
author: AUDRA M.

description: This place is fantastic! Great drinks, excellent food, and really cool decour. Definitely the perfect spot for a cocktail after work!
author: Joseph B.

description: Came in for drinks and apps to catch up with the boyfriend and had a great time. Staff is upper friendly and the food is really nice! Definitely be bac for more bar bites!!!
author: Jeanne R.

description: This quaint, hole in the wall (you would pass by it, if you weren't looking) French contemporary take on California cuisine is so wonderfully eclectic, you leave wanting more. The ambience is low key and the menu, mouth watering. My two sons ordered the smoked bacon flatbread which they loved. My husband had the tri tip sandwich, which he thought the meat was cooked perfectly. I wanted to order something light, so I ordered the charcuterie board. The board was filled with heavenly cheeses, meats, pickled vegetables and breads/crackers. It looked so good that my youngest (6) decided to eat half of the meat on the board. We will definitely come back when we are in town again.
author: K G.

description:
You'd think that downtown San Francisco, it of the large corporate office buildings and less-large but still full of employees buildings would have a bunch of places to grab drinks post-work without having to walk too far.

But if you're on 1st and Market (with the two big towers) you don't have a lot of choices. Sure, there's Louie's but it's packed by 3:30. Sutter Station? If you can find a seat after 5 I'm impressed.

Which is why I like Per Diem. Sure, they serve a fairly good businessperson's lunch special -- you know, the kind of lunch you take someone you're trying to impress or get a deal from (white cloth napkins and the whole deal). But after work it's never slammed and they serve a host of cocktails and beers without feeling like someone is just staring at the back of your head willing you to stand up and vacate the seat.

Sure, it's not cheap (think $12-14 for cocktails) but it's a good place to sit and hang out with a friend without having to fight a huge crowd.
author: Danny P.

description: Fantastic late lunch. We ordered the lagunitas aunt Sally sour ale, bear republic racer 5 IPA, charcuterie platter and the roasted mushroom flatbread and everything was lovely. Our server was also very pleasant and helpful.
author: Allison A.

description:
First time into Per Diem today.  I have eaten at many places for lunch in FiDi and non have the atmosphere or service.  Great experience entertaining family while in town for the week

The Croque Madame was amazing and tom is my favorite!!
author: Brandon B.

description: What can I say? I'm so glad I stumbled upon this hidden gem in FiDi - the food and service was top notch! The only restaurant I would match it with in terms of service is ABC Kitchen in NYC. The waiters at Per Diem were extremely attentive and made the experience that much better. I had the onion soup and the chicken quinoa kale salad which were great. The onion soup isn't too salty like it is at other places and the chicken salad was amazing. I don't even like kale! I'm excited to come back to try out their drinks and the bucatini.  Shoutout to the waiter with his hair tied back, u da best.
author: Caitlin B.

description: Went here for a partnership lunch and wow. When you walk in, the decor of everything is nice. Obviously, in the City, room can be tight but it feels more open than other restaurants. Went upstairs to where our work partner was and still felt roomy. Upstairs has a bar and also a small, outdoor seating area (I thought that was very nice). They changed the menu for the day so I had to look at the menu for the items of the day. Starters were the brussel sprouts (yum) and a few other items that I can't remember now but it was all delicious. Ordered the tri tip sandwich with fries (comes with ketchup and horseradish and a French dipping sauce). The portion was HUGE! Even for a guy who can eat, every bite was delicious and savory and filling. Well worth the food coma that came soon after. Service was busy but still refilled everything and took care of everyone in a timely manner. Overall, very happy with Per Diem.
author: A o S.

description: Went for lunch had the Tri tip sandwich and it was amazing.  Giving this a 3.5 because the service was subpar.  Waiter had a bit of an attitude and was not hospitable at all.  Would be a solid 4 had the service been on point.  Worth a return for the tri-tip sandwich.
author: Jay H.

description:
Definitely a fan! Came to Per Diem with a large group this week and the service and food were impeccable, start to finish.

To start, they hosted our crew in their private upstairs loft. I would live here if give the opportunity (and if SF rent wasn't ridiculous!). Yes, we were seated very close together, but what the heck do you expect for 20+ people in a small space for a seated dinner? 

A few of us arrived early and went to the downstairs bar for an aperitif! Love their setup, with stools around the L-shaped bar. Cocktails looked inventive and snazzy, but this gal went straight for the wine. 

Took our drinks back upstairs and indulged in a 3-course meal. Yumbo! First course was a choice of salads, which I had the basic greens. Nothing special, but it's difficult to get inventive with a basic green salad. A few people sitting close by had the summer squash and it look superb. Second course was the winner: lasagnette. Came in its own individual ramekin dish and was piping hot. Filled with pork and potatoes and lots of ooey, gooey cheese on top, definitely the best choice for a main. Other options included a papperdelle, swordfish or flatbread pizza. Lasagnette was the best. Final course was a chocolate roll, similar to the Little Debbie snacks we had as a kid. Only homemade and way better. They were so rich that every few seats shared a bite.

We had three severs dedicated to our party and they were spot on the entire meal. No one's water glass was left empty, everyone had at least a glass of wine and we all got our food at the same time. Not an easy feat with more than 5-10 guests at a time!

Kudos to Per Diem. Would love to come back for a more intimate experience.
author: Abby S.

description: 5 stars for the tri tip sandwich at lunch. Maybe the best French dip / tri tip style sandwich I've ever had. Salad is good. I've also had a pasta at lunch with an egg on it that was good (no tri tip, but good).
author: Sam B.

description:
I took a cab over from the mall after failing to do some last minute shopping - hate when that happens. My cab driver made an illegal turn onto Sutter from Market, bless his heart, and neither of us could find this place. We knew what side of the street it was on, but signage left something to be desired.  So I hopped out of the cab and skipped across the street in my heels.

There didn't seem to be a lot of action in the restaurant and the hostess ushered me upstairs to where our party was waiting.  Finally! An evening with friends after a long week.

I was surprised to see that they all had wine or beer on the table, yet the water glasses were still empty.  It took about 5 minutes or so for the waiter to stop by to greet me.  I asked for a Pisco Sour.  He said, "We don't have that here." I said, "Are you sure?  I mean do you know that you don't have Pisco or..."  He then told me to look at the Spirits List, although Pisco is not a spirit at all.  He finally resolved to go to the expert, the bartender.

Later he came back to tell me unfortunately they did not have Pisco on hand and offered their drink menu - but then walked away before getting my order.  How strange?  I had now been sitting at the table without water or a cocktail for over 10 minutes.  He did manage to take the appetizer order for everyone though.

Ok fine, fine...maybe I'm making this into something.  He then returned to ask for my drink and our mains.  We needed more time.  This was a birthday dinner and many of us hadn't seen each other nor spent time with each other since my wedding.  He skipped off and then like clock work, returned with my drink to ask us once again for our mains.  I looked up and saw the frustration on some of my co-diners faces.  We decided to go ahead though we really weren't ready and put them in.

The appetizers came out quickly which was great.  The pate was lovely and most likely not made in house.  The charcuterie plate was confusing and more pickled vegetable then anything else.  The little bit of cheese I did see was a nice selection but needed to be rationed between the table.  I almost felt guilty for eating any of it.

The main dishes finally arrived and we all cheered.  My husband had the filet with the lobster fries, I ordered the sole and my best friend ordered the mushroom pasta.  We immediately picked up our forks and started to try everyone else's food.  My husband's "lobster fries" were essentially cheese fries with lobster mixed in somewhere with some vegetables.  It was a pub version for sure, but lacking inspiration and flavor.  If it weren't for the fries themselves, it would've been worthless.  My dish on the other hand was awful.  I ordered the sole mainly because I hadn't been feeling well and it seemed like it would be the easiest on my tummy for now.  The sole was pan-seared (I think) but looked fried and came out incredibly dry.  The celery root puree barely made an appearance on the dish and was flavorless.  The brussle sprout side, though they did not glaze it in butter and oil like I ask was sad.  The vegetables were soggy, as was the bacon.  And how they were displayed on the rectangular plate looked like they weren't an official side at all but more like the kitchen was trying to do me a favor and get my greens in.

I don't think I'll ever be back unless I'm stuck in the Financial District without options...which as we all know, there are plenty of options in San Francisco.
author: Jessica C.

description:
My favorite lunch place in downtown sf. Unpretentious,  cute interior with a bit of touch from the "mad men"/prohibition era. High ceilings, copper carving, antique furnitures (one couch is perched 15 feet high shown high up in a window). Reminiscent of abc carpet in nyc. 

The food is delicious with a lot of attention to details. The burrata appetizer is fluffy, mixed with honey on top of the toast, perfect for sharing between two or three people. I also like the mussels.  

The pasta are ok but not the best in the city. The clam pasta was decent, but an occasional sand particle accompanied the clam and pasta was overcooked. The wild mushroom tagliatelle was so so, a bit watered down. I would probably stay away from pasta dishes here.  

The Brussels sprouts are a bit too soft for my liking.  

For a cold day, this place could get a bit drafty. I like upstairs seatings better.
author: Rebecca C.

description: I enjoyed a nice dinner with my brother on a rainy night.  The cocktails were good with a nice pour.  Had a petite sirloin with lobster fries, nice steak though slightly more than the medium requested.  The fries were yum but didn't need the onions included.  Brother had the squid ink pasta and said it was fine.  The shrimp included were a highlight.  Really nice looking place with decent food.  I would come back to try more.
author: Zillah T.

description:
I'll start with the positives. I really love the ambiance of this place. I came in for drinks with friends a while back before a concert and the drinks were great, my group and I got seated at a great table, and the service downstairs was both timely and friendly. 

Then I recently came here for dinner with my boyfriend, was seated upstairs, and while the ambiance is nice up there as well, the service this time around was not so good. While friendly, the waiter came around maybe twice and most of the time was no where to be seen when we needed something. The dish we both got for dinner was unimpressive and plain. We both ordered the squid ink pasta I believe it was, and it was the worst pasta I've ever had. And this is coming from someone who loves pasta, I can eat it plain with just butter, salt, and pepper. But this was something else. For the price, I was expecting to at least be able to tolerate it. 

My final advice, beware of what you order, maybe ask how much flavor certain dishes have. Because unless you want to feel like you're eating air, I would speak up ahead of time. I also hear this place is better for lunch. Maybe just skip dinner.

Overall I gave this place three stars for the ambiance and 50/50 good service. I had higher expectations of this place due to the reviews on here.
author: Melissa A.

description:
Came here for dinner during the week.  Street parking available right after 6p.  During the week, downstairs is the bar and upstairs is the dinner area.  Very interesting decor.  Looks like someone went to estate sales, flea markets, and garage sales to pick up anything that looked interesting.  Lots of wood upstairs.  Almost feels like you're in a wooden ship or cabin.  

Had the french onion soup and mixed green salad with burrata cheese.  Both were good.  The squid ink pasta with prawns and scallops was excellent.  The apple tart was a good dessert.  Enjoyed the meal, service was excellent.  The only issue I had here was that the menu was kind of limited.  

I'd eat again.
author: Doctor G.

description: This place is my go to for post work drinks. Arnie always keeps you entertained and definitely make you want to come back. Keep doing your thing PD
author: Charles A.

description:
Per Diem strikes me as a coy, rather self-satisfied name for this eclectically chic FiDi eatery. What this place has to do with anybody's daily allowance, I just don't know, although I could well imagine a lot of suits on expense accounts dining here to keep up appearances. The decor is apparently inspired by the 1849 Gold Rush with a predominance of dark woods and steel beams with a marble bar and a conspicuous chandelier encased in an oversized glass lantern. There's a 60's-style abstract painting of the Transamerica building at the bar which I assume is mounted there to remind you what city you're in. I've come here for lunch twice now, both times as a solitary diner at the bar just trying to test the limits of my plant-based dietary direction.

The first time I came I tried the $12 Panzenella Salad with Bloomsdale Spinach, which I thought was pretty good though a bit hamstrung from the puckery flavor of the fresh lemon oregano vinaigrette that was doused over it. It was mixed with chunks of roasted root vegetables, mostly turnips, and topped with shaved pecorino. The second time I visited, I ordered the $13 Berries and Rucola Salad, which was certainly pretty on the plate (see photo). The fresh raspberries and blackberries freckled the peppery greens and offered a nice contrast. It only came with two Shaft bleu cheese fritters, and I couldn't even taste the bacon lardons or even the bacon vinaigrette. On both trips, I ordered the $4 cup of Soup of Yesterday, which I assume was made for the dinner menu from the evening prior.

I must admit the soup was the best part of both lunches probably because in both cases, it was luxuriantly creamy. The most memorable was the Carrot Puree with a drizzle of what I assumed to be extra virgin olive oil infused with red peppers (see photo). Chef Adam Hinojosa comes from the more traditional Osteria, so the Italian accents in the dishes are to be expected here. I'm not sure if the upstairs room has more of a dining room ambiance since the downstairs area appears to be centered around the bar with a robust wine and cocktail menu. Perhaps I'll come back with some colleagues to try those. Right now, my impression is that the food is above average with prices that seem a tad excessive for the portions. I would really need a per diem to cover the bill.

FOOD - 3 stars...pretty good salads, soup is better even if it was made yesterday
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...nice decorator touches and quieter than you would expect, at least for lunch
SERVICE - 3 stars...reasonable, nothing more
TOTAL - 3 stars...middling until I try some of their other entrees, I hope
author: Ed U.

description:
On Saturday, 7/12/14, my girlfriend and I ate at Per Diem for dinner. I read a lot of mixed reviews on yelp but then again a lot of people on yelp don't know what they're talking about when it comes to good restaurants and food in general. 

Atmosphere/Decor: 

My girlfriend and I almost passed Per Diem up when we were driving by. It's in between what looks like to be a cafe and some type of shoe repair shop. I didn't know that Per Diem was located in the Financial District. The restaurant definitely stands out because there are no other restaurants surrounding it or near by. I really like this design of the restaurant from the exterior to the interior. Per Diem is a really nice restaurant! Who ever designed this restaurant did a great job! It's a very unique restaurant in my opinion. The huge brown entrance doors remind me of entering a castle or some type of mid evil establishment. The doors definitely enhance the overall visual effect of the exterior of the restaurant. 

When you enter the restaurant, you'll notice a huge bright chandelier that is hanging above. There are a few window shot tables located at the front of the restaurant. There's also a booth and a long stretch table closer to the bar area. The bar looked really nice and was a decent size. The painting located at the bar area blended very well with the overall theme and decor of the restaurant. Everything from the tables, real wood, flooring, and the granite looked very high end/expensive! I really liked the brick design located near the stairs leading up to the second floor. There are also two unique pillars that are resting on an area where they store bottles of wine. The lighting was dim and actually darkened throughout our dining experience.  

I was curious to see what was on the second floor so I decided to walk up there and take a look. The second floor is amazing! It looks beyond nice! There were plenty of tables to sit at, ranging from a table for two to large parties. The lighting gave off an intimate ambiance. There was also a patio roof area where you could walk out to and look in the sky. 

Food: 

We started out with the Flat Bread Del Giorgno (peaches, bacon, heirloom tomatoes, mozzarella, arugula and pepper oil.) The Flat Bread Del Giorgno was delicious! The taste of the crust was very good. The texture was very crisp. It was one of the best pizza crusts I've ever had. The peaches tasted really sweet but not too sweet. The peaches and bacon really complimented each other. The pepper oil gave it the right amount of heat. 

I ordered the Bucatini (pork bolognese all'arrabbiata, shaved pecorino, crispy
basil leaf) for my entree. Now this is how a pasta dish should taste! The pork bolognese was one of the best sauces I've ever tasted! The sauce was loaded with a lot of flavor and the pork tasted very good. The pasta was cooked perfectly! I can understand why people on here recommend it. 

My girlfriend ordered the Risotto (wild rice, farmers' market produce, parmesan, marscapone) for her entree. She liked the Risotto a lot! She said the veggies tasted really good and fresh. I had a few bites of her Risotto. I really liked the freshness of the veggies and the rice was cooked perfectly. 

Service: 

Our waiter Jorge was very nice and attentive. Jorge was very knowledgeable about the menu and actually recommended the Flat Bread Del Giorgno...He said it tastes really good, he was right! 

Overall: 

Per Diem definitely exceeded my expectations. This restaurant has it going on! If you want a nice atmosphere and reasonably priced delicious food, you should definitely come here!
author: David R.

description:
Burrata. Say it with me, folks. Burrrrrrrr-ahhhhh-taaaa. If you're ever having those "what am I doing with my life days?" while at a job you normally find a-okay, stop clicking your mouse around and go to Per Diem for some incredibly soft cheese, toasty bread, and your favorite work-time appropriate beverage. 

Even better, if you have more time, grab your favorite family member (I've dragged both my parents here on separate occasions, and an adult cousin, my brother, and a guy I went on one date with in Michigan) and enjoy a meal (might I recommend anything/everything?). And colleagues will think you're super suave if you invite them here for happy hour. 

It's not just the food and drinks that make this place stand out; the atmosphere is slightly hip-posh but the prices are reasonable for FiDi, the service is always impeccable, and while the noise factor is a little louder than my parents would like, if you ask to sit upstairs or in the back you'll be totally fine.
author: Alicia O.

description: Incredible staff and great ambiance! A fun place to grab dinner and drinks. The food is great, but don't come super hungry, the portions aren't huge.
author: Emily L.

description:
I came here with a group for a happy hour and the staff was incredibly accommodating.  They sat us in the patio area and explained that we would need to go down to the bar for drinks which wasn't a problem at all.  The bartender was great, friendly, and fast.  He even remembered our drinks when I went down to get the second round.

I've also eaten here for lunch in the past a long time ago and don't remember exactly what I got but remember the food being very good.  Very charming place!
author: Amanda K.

description:
I'll be the first to admit that prior to the change in head chefs, the quality had started to take a dive - At one point, I received a beet salad with beets that were so over-ripe, it was like chewing on gauze. Really pretty gross in terms of texture... That aside... 

Per Diem used to be a go-to for business lunches or the occasional lunch date, however since the new chef came on in recent months, changed the entire menu without warning, and drastically ran up the prices for a LUNCH menu, I'm not particularly interested in returning.

For $7, you can find yourself enjoying 5 leaves of butter lettuce, some red onion rings and a little dressing. For $30, you can get decent (but not necessarily impressive) salumi and fromage plates that almost equal a lunch for two. The croque madame is fine for $15, but dumping mornay sauce on a sandwich does not necessarily improve it. They have started making their sandwiches with some other bread than they were previously using and it simply underwhelms. The onion soup is too sweet (really lacking in salt and beef jus) and reminds me of something I would pick up at Safeway, not a quality French restaurant. 

I miss the fresh fish selection, the pork ragu, the salads that were actually meal-sized, the seasonal pasta selection. Seems like a waste to make a very sudden and drastic menu change when most things had been working fairly well prior to the kitchen change.
author: E. P.

description: Too bad, so sad.  I really wanted to love, love, love this place.  It's so close to my office and is, actually, a really cool space.  Alas, it wasn't meant to be.  As we walked in, it seemed that the host was just so over being there, which set the mood.  The place was about half-full towards the end of lunch, so we requested a table in the corner, but were told that our party of two could not sit there because he's holding it for a larger party.  There were other empty tables for 4, but ok. (Surprise, surprise - no larger parties walked in and our requested table remained empty the entire time we were there.) We sat at our two-top and waited ... and waited ... and waited.  It took a couple of attempts at flagging down a server before we were actually able to place our order.  To his credit, our server was sweet and charming - once we got his attention.  But it was just too little, too late.  There are soooo many other options within a 2-block radius.  You'll have better luck, elsewhere.  Cheers!
author: Bridget M.

description:
I love this place.  Granted, I've been in enough I know some of the staff and that's always a bonus, but the service staff is generally pleasant and more than on top of things.  
The Manhattan menu is kickin'...love the fact I can choose my bourbon and the bitters!! 
The food is fantastic considering there were obvious problems in the kitchen and with management several months ago.  After 18 years in the Hospitality industry these things are apparent. Fortunately, they were not apparent today...everyone was on top of things and ahead of the game!  The Manhattans were fantastic, the Roasted Beet, Laura Chenel Goat Cheese, Walnut, Oranges and Arugula Salad was great (presentation lacking) and the flatbread was delicious.  Well played Per Diem! Well played!!
author: Sean M.

description:
This is a good place for lunch meetings because the noise level is low and we can hear each other speak.  Not only that, the food they serve are super small and not filling, so, you won't feel overstuffed, lethargic and sleepy during your conversation on how to improve efficiency.

I ordered the $15 Crab Louie Salad.  When it arrived at our table, I couldn't find much crab in the salad.  There were literally 7 pieces of butter lettuce underneath 2 nice big plump shrimps, a 1/2 of a boiled egg, and itty bitty pieces of crab on the bottom of the bowl.  At least, I think it was crab, it was the color of crab but the pieces were so small I couldn't tell if it was crab.  This is the most pathetic crab Louie I've ever eaten in my life.

Good thing we ordered a side of fries for the table because I ate that as a filler.
