Otherwise, the service was friendly, the host wore super duper ka-juper tight Levi's jeggings pants and made for good light conversation at our table on wheither it would split in half if he squated..  And decor was dark and woody, once you enter, there is a chandelier that looked like it was stuck in the container box it came in,  The designer either couldn't figure out how to get it out of the crate or actually thought it was a good design concept?!!

At any rate, if you looking to spend big bucks for small portions that isn't worth the value, swing into Per Diem for a non-filling lunch meal!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Why 4 stars?  Because it was crabalicious.

   ---   ---   ---

First of all, this place has a really neat design to it.  Everything is old wood, like a western pub (for the locals, think Rye Bar) and it looks like it would be a pricy establishment, but the prices are actually moderate.

I couldn't decide between the crab melt or the oyster po boy, but crab won that battle, as it would in a real life battle.

I have no complaints about it at all, it was actually quite a delight.  The service was outstanding as well.

I wouldn't put Per Diem on the "OMG MUST TRY WHEN VISITING" list, but I'd put it on the list just below that, the "OMG SOOO SOLID, BRO" list.
author: Brett N.

description:
Cute environment with bar area on the first floor and what seemed to be a dining area upstairs.

I came here with a friend for a couple drinks and some appetizers. 
Garlic Fries - not bad and a generous portion
Cheese board and meats - this came with a sliver of a hard cheese that I can't remember and a generous serving of Burrata. I wish there was another cheese option or maybe the other hard option was a bigger piece? The portion of meats to cheese was off. The meat they had was serrano, salami and what looked like a ham? not sure. serrano is tough to me so didn't seem like a good meat to have on crackers since when you bite into it you end up taking the entire piece of meat with that one bite. Also, they provided thin crackers and a few pieces of sliced toasted baguettes, but those were too hard to eat so I stuck with the crackers.

I ordered a Hendricks martini, it was good and strong. But came with a price tag of $14 or $15.

Overall, it was an OK experience. I think a little pricey, but I may go back for convenience.
author: Tamara S.

description:
Too expensive. 9 dollars for a mousse, and I took it to go. Total was over 10 dollars.

It was really good, if not too sweet. I've had a similar mousse at Bellini's.
author: M R.

description:
2.5 STARS 

Fresh out of college and at my first office job was the first time I ever heard the term "per diem". Filing consultant contracts, I would be in awe of the payment terms "USD 1,000 per day plus $150 per diem". As I looked at my paycheck, I would silently curse at myself for ever majoring in Human Resources aka Professional Paper Pusher aka Office B*tch. 

From the people that brought you The Brick Yard (a sports bar in the Marina) comes Per Diem which is located in the epicenter of the Financial District. Boosting two levels and two bars with dark woods, bronzes, and steel beams the ambiance was reminiscent of the Gold Rush Era. The space screams M-O-N-E-Y which is correctly captured in their old money and new money cocktail list. Glancing over the $13 cocktails, I asked myself, "So THIS is what consultants use their per diem (daily allowance) for?" Again, I silently cursed at myself; talk about choosing the wrong career path. 

Although categorized as New American cuisine, Per Diem's menu is very Italian-centric. With 5 apps, 4 salads, 5 pasta, 4 entrees, and 3 pizzas options, I thought the menu was a bit scant (the online menu had more choices). Unless you're carbo loading for a marathon, there were few options. 

With my imaginary per diem to burn, I started with the Blue Chip Martini w/ Bleu Cheese & Olive Crostini ($13). http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MXy-YMQCWpBJf92HFRhGhw?select=4yVLomcsA_-c0l1U4g3Jsw Worth every penny, the Nolet's Gin martini was stiff and made for one "happy" hour sans the happy price.  

We started our meal with the PEI Mussels in a Fennel Sausage Broth ($12). http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MXy-YMQCWpBJf92HFRhGhw?select=6havZYT-e-fqvAcXcJ-MSA What the mussels lacked in size, the complexity of the broth made up in flavor. The rich, herbaceous broth was intensified with the small chunks of fatty sausage. I think "spicy" was inadvertently omitted from the title as the broth packed quite a powerful and lingering heat. 

Everything was going seemingly well until I got my entree. The Braised Tomato Truffle Brisket, Lentils & Marinated Cipollini Onions ($21) was a disaster on a plate and should have never left the kitchen.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MXy-YMQCWpBJf92HFRhGhw?select=mjnQ_DyMJRmv3A6qypco1w The brisket bricks were severely underseasoned and not braised long enough (to break down the collagen in the connective tissue) causing the texture to be that of shoe leather. Instead of a butter knife, a chain saw should have been included with this dish. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MXy-YMQCWpBJf92HFRhGhw?select=BsSgdKyB2osonsfzswGb9w The accompanying lentils were overcooked to a prison food mush. Tomatoes? Truffles? I think they were playing hide & seek on me as not even an essence was present. 

Service was pleasant but unpolished; understandable for a restaurant open less than three months. However, simple things like providing new utensils (after taking ours away) and refilling BOTH our water glasses were overlooked. 

Though Per Diem has solid cocktails, their menu and food need work. I'll be back though...the day I have the luxury of a per diem. Until then, I will happily enjoy my $2 Gordon's Gin & Tonic at the Tappa Kegga Dayya brotherhood event at City Tavern in the Marina on Tuesday nights. PUMA NIGHT! *WOOT*
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Place was nice, like the decor, atmosphere，。just wish the level of food is higher.  Onion soup was good, nothing to write home about.  Squid ink pasta was fine but had a bit too much texture that doesn't like andante.  Just strange, no squid ink flavor even its black.  Good for lunch meeting.
author: CAScuba Y.

description:
I've only been here for happy hour and appetizers after work, and it was a solid experience. It's such a small and unassuming place, it's hard for me to believe this little spot has been on Sutter St for as long as it has been.

There are a number of tables in the bar area, but I generally love to sit at the bar....which is where I've parked myself the last couple of times I've been to Per Diem. The bartenders have always been nice and quick, always keeping our glasses full. They have a few different wines by the glass, including prosecco, and my go-to apps order is poutine. Did I mention they have poutine? Love poutine.
author: Wendy L.

description: I came here for an early lunch with a friend and was not disappointed. We split the Burrata Tartine and I had the Salmon Nicoise, which were both delicious. Everything is pretty reasonably priced given the area, and service was quick and efficient for the working lunch crowd. The only downside was that they really packed us in upstairs and it felt a bit cramped and loud, but it might be a nice space for a larger group gathering and I'd definitely be back for the food.
author: Rachel A.

description: Travelling for business, I ate at the bar.  The ambiance, food,drink and service here are very good.  While I didn't have one, I got the see Arnie the bartender make all of the high dollar specialty cocktails.   They probably taste as good as they look.  The food was super and very fairly priced.   If you're in the Financial District I recommend this spot for drinks and/or dinner.
author: Steve S.

description:
My coworkers and I took our new office intern to lunch. He chose Per Diem as his restaurant choice. We made a reservation for 12:45pm which is prime lunch time here in the Fidi. We had to wakt maybe 5-10 mins for our table. 

My coworkers and I shared a dozen oysters to start and ordered their fresh baked bread (complete w/ dipping sauces). I ordered the margarita pizzette which had heirloom tomatoes on it. It was okay. Not the best and not the worst but hit the spot and cured my lunch hunger pains. 

I probably would go back and try their dinner sometime. But nothing stood out to me during lunch.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: This is the most awesome little tavern . Sometimes working in the city gets hectic and always nice to leave work early with friends and catch up with a glass of vino. Hospitality is awesome . Make sure you make a reservation especially if you go there for lunch .
author: Celia J.

description:
After being open only a few months, my friend and I decided to give this Californian/Italian eatery a whirl.  I made reservations for last night at 6pm through opentable.com.  Though their menu prices slightly differ from their online menu, entrée prices are reasonable considering you're in the Financial District.  

FOOD:
*Steamed PEI Mussels ($12) - Good and exceeded my expectations.  Although the mussels were a bit on the smaller side, the fennel sausage broth was delicious!  Generous pieces of sausage added additional flavor to the already flavorful broth.  Do beware, it is a bit spicy.

*Cioppino ($19) - So delicious!  The tomato broth was thick and hearty with a slight kick.  Per Diem does not use fish or fish stock (yay for me since I'm allergic!), but shrimp stock instead.  Mussels, deshelled prawns, calamari, and shredded crab meat were added to the stew.  You'll definitely make use of the accompanied grilled crostone.  The serving size is enough for one without you feeling overly full.  Since we had an appetizer, I ended up bringing half my cioppino home.

Both dishes are highly recommended!  My friend had the truffle brisket and it looked quite dry.

SERVICE:
Though the food is four star worthy, the service area is where they were lacking.  Our waitress was nice, but we felt like the service portion was missed throughout our meal:
*After receiving the menus, our order wasn't taken until 20 minutes later
*We weren't told the specials, I had to ask her
*Our appetizer plates were not taken away before our entrée plates were brought out
*I had a fork and knife, but didn't have a spoon...how was I to eat my cioppino? 
*My water glass was filled, my friend's glass was not even though she had less water than I did

PARKING: 
Metered street parking which is relatively easy to find after 6pm.
author: Nicole S.

description: My BFF took me out to dinner here in April 2016. He's always got the best restaurant recommendations, because he's a native New Yorker. Per usual, Per Diem did not disappoint. I ordered the Lamb shank with truffle risotto. Fabulous! Also loved the traditionally classy decor.
author: Sally M.

description: Do this! If you wander off the beaten track in the Financial district - stop here. This place was a hidden gem. Loved it! The staff in this empty bar was so friendly and helpful. Delicious craft cocktails were skillfully prepared. And the place looks really cool too. We got lucky finding Per Diem. Cheers!
author: Michael D.

description: Super cool little spot. Hung out at the bar with the wife and in-laws...place was great! Wood and brick higher end vibe. Cool music and cool drink. It's a 30s + type place, loungy. We had the smoking mule (really smokey flavor, like the liquid smoke cuz of the mescal...but delicious). Had the citrus trade (great), MXN (perfect of sweet and hint of spice) and a regular Moscow mule (good). We got a little buzzed but we came in on an empty stomach! :) Will be back! This place is a hidden gem!
author: Nick M.

description: The service here is amazing. We had a reservation and were seated immediately. The seating is up a narrow staircase. It is a dark room as well. For my appetizer I ordered the mussels which were lovely. The white whine sauce was perfectly seasoned and a decent portion. For the main course I had the steak and lobster. The steak was done nicely and the lobster was nice and rich.
author: Amelie S.

description: Service was excellent, and the ambience was nice. But the serving sizes were very small. I had the squid ink linguini. The scallops and shrimp were excellent, but the pasta was dry. No salad or soup included, so the $26 price was excessive. Probably not a place I would return to.
author: Alex P.

description:
Not impressed at all.  

Remember that scene in Seinfeld where Jerry explains what the term "reservation" means to an uninterested counter lady?  That was my introduction to Per Diem. The girl at the front tried to seat us at a little table right in the foyer, right where people where standing.  When we refused that and insisted that we be seated at a table not located right by the entrance, we were told that no tables were available.  Only when we started to leave did a table on the upstairs terrace magically open up.  And surprise--there were three empty tables up there!

Service was worse--I think she wanted to turn the table in the worst way because she kept interrupting us. Here's a hint--let people finish their sentences before barging in.  Good servers know to do that and she was definitely not a good server.

Oh, and the food....wish I'd left when I had the chance.  Apparently, at Per Diem, "medium well" means "raw and pink" on the inside of your burger. 

Waste of time and money.
author: Jack K.

description:
Made reservations for lunch, arrived with a party of 4 and was seated right away.

Decor was very rustic and inviting. Sat upstairs, noise volume was low. Food was delicious.

We tried:

Burrata on crostini with honey on top (aptz)
Steamed mussels (with pieces of sausage)
Beet salad
Caesar
Mushroom pizza
Bucatini-pasta with tomato meat sauce
Pappardelle- with mushrooms

Absolute delicious! Really liked the burrata and the mussels were the best tasting I've had... So good try them.
author: Azizi A.

description:
Hesitated writing this review, but compelled to do so. Went on a Saturday night to celebrate my son's 31st. Table of four, with a 7:15 open table reservation. 

Upon entry, felt like I was home! I loved the decor, gorgeous restaurant. It is a place where I could see myself going alone! With pleasure. 

The service left too much to be desired. And the food? Ditto. Took way too long to get drinks once ordered, but mine was rather good upon arrival. Had a $32 ribeye that was nonexistent. The apps were good, and the beet salad was terrific! Should have stuck with the apps.

But, I cannot get over a confrontational waiter. He and one of my guests clearly rubbed each other the wrong way. And since it was a birthday celebration I expected we'd be having dessert and we did not. Come to find out it was because of said confrontational waiter...

Now look, dinner cost me $300 and I'm okay with it. However, don't be dissin anyone when you're working for a tip. You cannot let your wait staff cop attitude, ever, with a paying customer. Just wrong on every level.

So, as we all know, there are lots of restaurants in SF and we can choose any of them. The experience is what matters, even with substandard food. Don't be rude to customers and perhaps they won't be rude back. We don't need it.
author: Elizabeth Q.

description:
Been back here a number of times now since my first review and I feel compelled to update. 

Both their service and their food is hit or miss.

Consistently good: Buactini and Caesar Salad. 
Pizzas: Mediocre..to much crust and not enough good stuff. It is a bit small for the price. 
Dungeness Crab melt - Skip. Too buttery and greasy. 
Poutine - It needs to be served piping hot. I've gotten it during happy hour and each time was declious. I got it during lunch yesterday and after sitting for a few mins on the table the fries were all soggy and the cheese just coagulated. It was borderline disguesting. 

Overall, not a place I'd recommend or do an important business meal.
author: Mimi T.

description: The food was great and the wine was a good one, but the staff was coming to our table nonstop all the time and it was really annoying!
author: Gabriela W.

description:
The food is not bad, but the FiDi tax hurts. 

Per Diem has a cool trendy atmosphere, friendly service, and a full bar. I really like their comfortable booths for a more relaxing and intimate small group dinner. 

I tried to make-my-own Manhattan cocktail, choosing the whiskey, vermouth, and bitter. I must say it turned out pretty tasty. 

As appetizers we tried half a dozen oysters and the roasted bone barrow. The bone marrow was good, and the oysters were not bad either. They were a bit on the small side though, and at $3 each they were definitely not cheap. 

Their cioppino was good. It had the right flavors, it was a bit spicy, and was loaded with a good amount of seafood (primarily mussels and shrimp).  It had been a while since I had had a good cioppino, so I thoroughly enjoyed it. 

I enjoyed my meal, but when I saw my bill was around $80, I said ouch.
author: Augusto T.

description:
Did I just walk into a set of The Pirates of the Caribbean?

Slow service.  Showed up 10 min. early for reservation and host acted like we showed up too early.  Got seated 7 min. after reservation.  Ordered beverages and took a while for those to come to the table.  Food was delicious.  Took some time to get the bill...had to go to the counter to ask for it.

Great burger...the pimento cheese.  Onion finely sliced, as if shaved.

Oyster Po'Boy...really tasty but messy.

Ginger beer tasted watered down and flat.
author: Michelle N.

description:
+/- THE FOOD
The food was very visually appealing but the flavors were just lacking! Starting with the drinks, I had the MXN and it was WAY too spicy. Those jalapeno peppers made it really hard to drink. My friend and I shared the steamed mussels and fries together. The mussels tasted good but they were super tiny and there was a lot of them that were unopened. The fries were really undersalted, which is really sad. For the main courses, my friend ordered the wild mushroom pasta and I had the squid ink linguine. I definitely liked my friend's pasta better but it was pretty heavy. I liked the lemon cream flavors of my dish's sauce and the seafood was cooked really well. However, the flavor of the actual pasta was really boring and bland. For dessert, my friend and I shared the creme brulee and warm apple tart. The creme brulee was NOT good and was a huge disappointment.... until I tried the warm apple tart and that was even worse. The apple tart tasted like an old apple muffin that was crumbling everywhere. 

- THE SERVICE
We came during happy hour time but we made reservations so our hostess seated us up on the second floor and to the very back of the restaurant. Initially, I was really glad she did that since it was really loud downstairs. However, this caused us to be hugely ignored the entire time we were dining here. It would take forever for our server to come check up on us and we were often sitting there for a long period of time without anyone walking by.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Although the wait might be long, it's quite worth it. The pizza alone is to die for but the pasta and sandwiches look killer as well. I'm only a first-timer but I can honestly say that they haven't seen the last of me.

If you've got an appetite.  Try the Meatball pizza.  YUM!
author: Kevin J.

description: An amazing experience at this place. Monica and Arnie were our bartenders and really took care of us! Monica had a lot of great recommendations. Nelson was very friendly too and took care of us when the bartenders were busy! Definitely a great experience. Grab a Manhattan while you're there....you wont regret it!
author: Mark A.

description:
Finally got a chance to check out Per Diem and really liked it. it has a small storefront and is easy to miss but opens up very nicely into a larger restaurant.  I really liked the cool vibe and the decor. We started off in the bar area where I grabbed a couple of excellent Old Fashions. We headed upstairs for dinner into a nice cozy area.

The food was very good. We got to try several appetizers and the burrata toast was my favorite, sooo good. The meatballs were a close second.  The cheese plate was a little underwhelming. The mac and cheese, beet salad and ribs were good. Only nit would be that everything was a little too rich and the ribs especially did not need all that butter.  I admit, I perhaps ate too much but the richness did not help. I had to run another mile at the gym the next morning to mitigate some of the guilt.
author: Sunil R.

description: Such a great find in the city! I'm lucky that my friend is a local and took me to check the place out. Really high quality food and fun ambiance.
author: Shannon S.

description: I wanted to try this restaurant while I was in SF. I made a reservation for Saturday 10/1 at 8pm, got to the restaurant and it was closed for a private event?!?! Why would it give me an option to make a reservation!
author: Samantha C.

description: Such a beautiful restaurant and bar ambiance.  The perfect place for dinner and drinks and the most beautiful spot to take pictures afterward!  You must try the French onion soup and the steak (medium rare) was to die for!!  Noel was such a fun and energetic server and was always there as soon as our drinks needed a refill (and we like to drink!). Will for sure be back soon :).
author: Jenna H.

description: Per Diem is a hidden FiDi gem!! A friend and I came in for drinks and some food on Saturday and were very pleasantly surprised. The host, Emily, was so nice and helpful. She recommended that we sit in the bar area which worked out great. The bartender Monica took fantastic care of us and made us drinks tailored to our specific tastes. There was also a very friendly server (Griffin) that was super engaging and I think we'll try to come back some time to get put in his section. Overall great experience and excellent music.
author: Zoe S.

description:
Just ok.

Decor and vibe is stellar.  Exposed brick, rustic leather, sturdy wood.  Very cool.  The "manhattan project" allowed me to put together the ingredients for a fool proof and very delicious manhattan. Plus one for that.

The food...eh, not bad.  Split an order of french onion soup.  Very nice, and just the way french onion should be, or at least so I thought.

My partner's squid ink pasta was fantastic with a nice light buttery cream type sauce. The portion seemed a little small.

My roasted chicken...dry.  Presentation was wonderful, skin was crispy, but the meat was dry.  Disappointing.  And the accompanying sauce and potatoes/olives/capers all seemed a bit muted and bland.

1 appetizer, 1 drink, and 2 entrees was $86 with tax and tip included.  Seems a bit steep, especially when the chicken was dry and uneventful.  But still a nice dinner none the less.  I would consider going back (this was actually my 2nd time), but it's definitely not a first, or even second, choice.
author: T. G.

description: pretty good food; i ordered the prime rib dip, but not 5-star worthy. though friendly, the service was a tad slow, and the tables can extremely close together, which i didn't appreciate very much that tables next to me can clearly hear my conversation. i would go back, but probably not on the top of my list.
author: Mike C.

description:
This is a great place to stop in to for lunch and dinner.   The lunch menu is simple with more extensive dinner options. 

The ambiance of the place is perfect with a cozy upstairs.  

I really enjoyed my meal: 
App - Cheese plate
Entree - ravioli with a side of brussel sprouts. 
Dessert - Lemon Tart

Delicious!
author: Erin W.

description: Long wait for a table of 7 that has been reserved for ages for the birthday party of an 80 year old. Salad Niciose was horrible - no dressing, white lettuce, white cooked tuna. Zero flavor. Wait staff was considerate though
author: Tina J.

description:
Just had dinner with my best friend  at this fabulous restaurant! Our server Noel was so cool and gave us great recommendations! The food was amazing!!! 5 stars all the way for this place! Atmosphere, service, and food were 100%!!! 
Thanks we will be back soon!
author: Lindsay B.

description: Absolutely amazing filet- it was so tender I could cut it with the side of my fork!  The red wine reduction that it is served with is the perfect compliment.  The beer selection is fair and the charcuterie should not be missed!  The lobster fries were good (though it is definitely Pacific lobster) though I recommend a side of aioli and a bit of salt to enhance the flavors.
author: Lindsey P.

description: Wow! SUCH a great restaurant, in particular, Monica was fantastic as a bartender... I will DEFINITELY be coming back just for the drinks alone! They are tasty and fancy without being too pricey, a rare find in such an expensive city!
author: Jianna M.

description:
The theme is money (just look at their cocktail menu), so guess that's why this seems to attract the suit and ties for after work?  Well, besides the fact that it's smacked dab in the middle of a great spot in FiDi.  It helps that it's not bad to look at either (some grandeur booths, exposed concrete, dark wood, a beautiful chandelier).  

A couple of coworkers and myself met a client here a few months back around 4 on a weekday.  We were able to snag a booth, but with the small size of the seating space and it being in FiDi, it got very busy as we ended our meeting.  Service was fine and we ordered some drinks and light bites.  I got a pisco punch and it was perfectly balanced and so refreshing.  For light bites we shared a veggie flatbread and oxtail poutine.  The flatbread was probably my favorite of the two although the oxtail poutine was a good snack for pairing with cocktails.  I haven't had poutine since Salt House a few years ago, as it's not that easy to find here and is so rich & heavy.  Not a bad place for drinks and bites, though still a little pricey, but then again, it is FiDi.

I actually tried to get a table for a party of 12 shortly after Per Diem opened up about three years ago.  It was a little holiday reunion dinner with 11 other girls I went to elementary school with.  I called to ask if I could make a reservation and they said no because of their small size, and weren't very apologetic/sympathetic.  I don't have much knowledge of the restaurant industry, having not ever worked in a restaurant, but I thought this was kind of rude and also a dumb move, because, who wouldn't want to be guaranteed that money?  Especially since restaurants on Fridays and the weekends in FiDi aren't that busy because everyone is going/at home.  Though, I came here a few months ago per our client's request, I guess I can forgive Per Diem for this, but I'm not sure if I would ever come here myself unless someone else picks the tab up, just because that still doesn't sit well with me.  

3 stars for now for the good service here though during our visit, some good drinks and not too shabby bites.
author: Cat C.

description:
Met a client here thanks to it's close proximity to transit. I

f going for dining, I'd recommend getting reservations for lunchtime and requesting a seat upstairs.. The decor is very rustic and bold ( I know... bold?). I npticed a small outdoor seating area on the 2nd floor also. 

I'd love to quote the lamb dish that I had, but their online menu is outdated.

Overall ornate restaurant in the heart of downtown. Can't go wrong.
author: Samuel C.

description:
Went here for lunch this week with my work team.

It's a very cool place visually and it was very busy.

The food was good, but not necessarily memorable. But they did accommodate me taking out the starch and giving extra veggies.

I would probably come again if someone was footing the bill but probably wouldn't chose it on my own.
author: Alexis M.

description:
Gentlemen if you're looking for a nice place to bring your date I wouldn't recommend Per Diem but if you're looking to unwind with drinks after work or dine with friends, then this seems like a good spot. I walked in and my first impression was 'wow this is bougie' but what do you expect from the Financial District? 

At 7 pm on a weekday night it was incredibly loud downstairs by the bar. Like imagine sitting really close to your friend just so you can shout at them "WORK IS GOING GREAT!" If you're trying to have a conversation with your dining companions I would direct you to the upstairs, which feels like an imitation of a rich guy's home library, complete with shelves lined with books that people buy purely for decoration and random cushy armchairs in between tables. The lighting is dimmed, giving it a more intimate atmosphere.

I had the pinot noir, which hit the spot, and for apps we ordered burrata and pork belly. I had cioppino for my main dish. Burrata is a type of Italian cheese on grilled crostone (bread) with honey, sea salt, and toasted almonds. It tastes like greek yogurt lite and the consistency is a little funny and runny. It tasted fine, but it's something you could whip up pretty easily yourself. You could spend your money better elsewhere. The pork belly was succulent and soft and it comes with broccoli rabe and a cute lil baby egg. The cioppino comes with shrimp, crab, mussels, and calamari in a tomato saffron broth with crostone. The seafood tastes fresh and really pops with the broth but it is the most expensive entree on the menu.

Our waitress was very friendly (never seen that many smiles in one meal) and very knowledgeable about the drink menu. We were also sitting there after everyone else had left and the restaurant was about to close and she never rushed us but did ask if we wanted dessert before the kitchen closed. Overall it was a nice experience but I don't think I would go back unless I suddenly became a hotshot SF financier with money to burn and a suit to wear for cocktails.
author: Alice L.

description: I was disappointed. Service was subpar, and food was no better. We had burratta flatbread, beet salad, and seafood linguini. Uninspired is the best word I can come up with. 80 bucks later...
author: Rick S.

description:
In order of best to worst:

Atmosphere: Terrible on a Thursday evening. Loud, blaring music, overdressed, snooty people and creepy businessmen ogling you. I didn't realize weeknight dinners were supposed to feel like raves

Food: The Salumi Plate, despite being big, featured rather forgettable cuts of pork. The accompaniments were all over the place, with pickled vegetables that were way too sour (and I LOVE sour), breadsticks that felt like pencils and slices of bread that tasted stale. The Risotto with English peas, asparagus and wild mushrooms was delicious at first bite until I realized it was way over-salted. Shame too, because I loved the combination of risotto, crispy peas fresh asparagus and delicious, crunchy mushrooms

Drinks: The Bimbo was pretty and fruity and sweet and everything girly. Get

Service: Good. Friendly. No complaints

I think the biggest turn-off about Per Diem was the vibe. The upstairs dining room was fine and decorated in a unique way, but the downstairs bar was just a nightmare of loudness and snootiness and pretentiousness. Considering you have to go through all of that to get to the hostess stand (especially if you enter through the hallway entrance), the whole thing just doesn't seem worth it to me.
author: Josephine L.

description: I went there last night for a cocktail and ended up staying for dinner after taking a look at the menu.  Anna the manager was super cool, friendly and accommodating as was the rest of the very kind staff.  I ended up having a delicious fillet mignon that came with lobster fries...yes you read that right....LOBSTER FRIES - chunks of lobster tail and peppers tossed through crispy fries. Any place that is brilliant enough to come up with something that amazing deserves a good yelp review from a picky foody like me........mic drop
author: Shaz D.

description:
When in the heart of the financial district this is one of the best places for happy hour. The food is amazingly delicious and whatever type of drink you need they have it for you. 
Seating can be a little limited but for me it's worth it. 
The atmosphere is super relaxing
author: Blake R.

description:
The restaurant is located in an old, cozy building on a side street.  We were seated upstairs.  The interior has a bookish feel, as though one happened to be in an old library.  Except that it served food, drink and wasn't pin drop quiet.
My husband, who felt like he had been eating his way through San Francisco on business, suggested we order a lighter meal.  We shared the cheese plate, which also featured currants and candied nuts.  The cheeses were excellent, although we ran a bit short on crostini.  We each had a salad.  He had the panzanella, and I chose the little gem and beet salad.  Both salads were tasty.  I adore beets, and the goat cheese vinaigrette complimented.
Next time in San Francisco, I would like to explore Per Diem's menu further.  If my husband happens to be having a fat day, he can have one by himself.
author: Robin C.

description: Quaint and casual restaurant. Great service by the hostess and waitress. I had the Roasted Chicken and it was delicious! The chicken was cooked perfectly -- juicy inside and perfectly crispy on the outside. Fantastic flavor surrounded by yummy artichoke hearts and finger potatoes.
author: Omar C.

description:
My friend and I had our annual holiday lunch here.  I wish I can say I like Per Diem but I'm meh on it for the following reasons:

1)  It took 40 minutes for them to serve us any kind of food at all.  It's the tail end of the lunch rush so I don't understand why service was so slow.  People, we have to go back to the office, how hard is it to cook a burger and a quarter of a chicken?  You lost our dessert business because we were afraid we will be stuck until happy hour here.

2)  Mary's chicken was flavorful but too salty for my tastes.  The veggies acted more like garnishment than sustenance.  You don't even get a half chicken.  It looks like you get a drumstick and a 1/4 of a breast.  Not worth the $15.

3)  Insult to injury, they tacked on an extra 4% healthy sf surcharge.  As I said before this is such a passive aggressive move by restauranteurs.  Really, just add it to the cost of the menu.  That surcharge is disingenuous at best.  Do the staff actually benefit from this or are you pocketing the monies at the end of the year like some fake SF restaurants.  IRS - taxable income right there if they keep it.

4)  We were not offered bread.  Bread would help considering the chicken was miniscule.

On the other hand, the burger that my friend had was good. I should have ordered that but who wants to have McDonald's food when you eat at places like this?  Decor was nice but a tad dark.  The lights were too dim to read the menu.

Service was meh.  No status on the meal, they didn't check in on us at all, nothing.

Will we be back? No.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Writing another review regarding the service this time.

I often direct people to this place or bring people from out of town who want a great meal at a reasonable price and have always felt that the restaurant deserves a higher overall star than it has, however...

I took my mom and her partner to dinner here this week.  They were visiting from South Africa and after a day of sightseeing were dressed casual, but not unpresentable.  When I walked in the host blatantly gave them the once over and then said that they were full but a table had paid but it was going to take 20-30 minutes before they left (he didn't even check the screen for the table seatings upstairs).  The comment was clearly meant to deter us from eating there.  

I feel a little shunned, my parents were not dressed terribly.  But then again, maybe I'm wrong, maybe it was just my face he didn't like. :P

Please note though: the food was excellent and this time I think value for money when compared to other nearby restaurants.
author: Julie B.

description:
Let's get right to it.

Lovely atmosphere, dark grainy wood, terrific décor, the kind of place that lulls a conversation into a dreamy nap. This is a wonderful space and I'd return for the feel alone. 

The food was very good, not great. I did expect a touch more artistry in each course-let me take that back, the chocolate dessert, whatever it was called, was truly inspired. But the rule held true for the rest. The Organic Greens Salad was precisely the salad I envisioned when I read the title, and while that's not a bad thing, a restaurant with this kind of potential should take advantage of my taste buds. Molest them, even. I had a taste of the romaine salad, I gotta say, not much going on there. Mary's Chicken reminded me of a more polished version of the bird I cook on a regular basis at home: flavorful, juicy, the potatoes were delish, but there wasn't much more to it. Lest I forget the pea shoots nestled alongside, those were marvelous.

So I'll say this for Per Diem: you're on the right track. Clearly consistency is highly valued and emphasized. Nailed it. Now go off the beaten track a little, would ya? It will give the fare a much-needed personality boost.
author: Howie K.

description: Hands down the best bartender I have seen since moving from the east coast. (Arnie) Great pace, very understanding of all patrons and all knowing on what is going on in the bar.   Five Stars.
author: Eric F.

description: I went in last night for a drink and was extremely happy with the service and knowledge of the bartender Arne. I was not sure what I wanted when I sat down. Based on a few quick questions, not only did he make me a great drink, but educated me in the process. I will definitely be coming back here asap!
author: Thomas L.

description:
I've been several times for lunch only and love this place. Great food and I really like the room. It gets busy and without a reservation I've usually sat at the bar. I need to try it for dinner sometime.

Most recently tried the lamb sugo which came with brussels sprouts and root vegetables over a creamy polenta. Lamb was very tender and flavorful with a nice jus that was delicious over the polenta.
author: Rade S.

description:
Had lunch here for a special event with co-workers and with all the different eaters we had, no one left unsatisfied.

The ambiance is nice, I love the little outdoor seating area, and my chicken sandwich was delicious. I also loved the brussel sprouts. I'd go again and recommend it as a lunch spot for meetings. 

The pricing is a bit on the high side, even for SF lunch standards, so this isn't an everyday spot.
author: Donna H.

description:
I order lunch here every couple weeks. The Per Diem burger is excellent. Top it with a fried egg and voila. The decor has swag and this would be a great place to take friends from out of town.

This place is a bit small so although intimate, the noise level can be high.
author: Thomas Nathan S.

description: Great atmosphere, outstanding cocktails...hip little spot to grab a drink...if your lucky you'll catch Alexa...the best bartender in town.
author: Sam R.

description: Had a lovely dinner out on a Saturday night at Per Diem.  Very nice place!  Comfortable environment with great service and top notch food.  Great fresh ingredients used in every dish.  Build your own Manhattan is a great idea!  Very impressive.
author: Tim H.

description:
The majority of dinners I attend during my frequent work trips to SF are for 20-25 people. I've seen the good, bad and the ugly when it comes to group dinners...and Per Diem is most definitely on the good list.

My party of 25 took over the gorgeous room upstairs, which was set-up in the shape of a square. It was so ideal that we could actually play an icebreaker and hear every individual sitting at the table. I can't remember the last time we had such a perfect set-up for a large group dinner!

The servers were on top of their game and got the food out very fast. As for the food it was very tasty. We had pre-selected options for the appetizers and entrees. I started with the pancetta salad followed by the pesto pasta. Both were so delicious and relatively large portions. I was full pretty early on, but it was too good to stop...which I kinda regretted later on as I entered a food coma.

For dessert they brought platters of chocolates for everyone to share. It was the perfect ending to the meal and locals were especially happy as they watched the Giants win the world series on the TV in our room.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Appropriately named Per Diem in the heart of the Financial District, your daily food budget (per diem) must include a trip to this "new" American cuisine restaurant.  A cornucopia of American classics, Italian rustic, whole animal, and locavore in flair, I would come back tomorrow if I could for the Bucatini. Chicago and San Francisco are pretty far apart, but paying tribute to their support of local flavors, I can still taste this dish in my mouth like it's right around the corner. 

The next time I'm in San Francisco I'd like a repeat please. For starters, the Organic Local Green Salad was delightfully light and flavorful, and the perfect introduction to my hearty portion of Bucatini. Plump and tender spaghetti-like noodles covered with a generous topping of rich seasoned soft ground pork, this dish literally melted in my mouth like butter. That might explain why I honestly couldn't stop eating it, even when I could feel my stomach bulging with goodness. I'm also a sucker for pecorino cheese, so that could have something to do with it too.

The location of this place is easy to get to, but because of its uniqueness, it caught me off guard when I had to walk into and through a mall-like atmosphere to find the entrance. Once in the door, this place is an open concept charmer with dark woods, shelves of books around the outer edges, old globes, and chicken wire cabinets. Italy meets barn-like goodness here in décor. 

A great place for parties of approximately 20 or so people, the upstairs is perfectly suited for this. Part of a business dinner of this size, our group took up the entire upstairs front room yet it was cozy and not too compact. I also liked the fact I could see everyone I was dining with. 

Great wine, excellent service, and need I say anymore about the Bucatini?
author: Angela S.

description: Love this place!  Sat at the bar (Walk in), last Friday for a drink with another friend. Grace (think that's her name- Asian gal bartender) very sweet.  She made a hibiscus concoction drink which was absolutely amazing.  Very friendly staff all around and great food.  I will definitely be back.
author: Nalini L.

description: Filet mignon and lobster fries were out of this world.  Also particularly enjoyed the tempura asparagus.
author: Jason G.

description:
The scene: early dinner at Per Diem with Josephine L. on Friday evening. Downstairs at the bar: deafeningly loud and chaotic as all heck. Upstairs in the dining room: calm, cool and collected.

The food: we started with the charcuterie plate which was large (easily shared between 3 or 4 people) and had several cuts of cured meat. I did think a small improvement in better bread selection and slightly less pickled vegetables would have made this a 4-star plate. For our entrees, I had the bucatini which came in a meat ragu sauce. It was very oily which later gave me a tummy ache, but was pretty good overall. If I could make a suggestion I'd say more chunky tomato, less oil and butter.

The drinks: I had a pimm's cup which was good, a little weak.

The service: Service was friendly but kind of absent. Our waitress didn't check on us but luckily we didn't need anything.

Overall I'd say this was pretty good, but given the cost I can't say I'd rush back.
author: Rachel E.

description:
I really don't understand how this place only has 3.5 stars?  I met up with my bf here for lunch, and granted it was right after a holiday and the typical lunch hour crowd was probably on vacation, but we had a great and seamless experience.

I made reservations online ahead of time, met up at this very unassuming place, and was blown away.  Our waitress was awesome!  She was sweet and attentive, without creepily being around us or being awkwardly and insincerely too nice.  

I had the Tri-tip sandwich and it was heavenly!  It wasn't the healthiest of meals; the bread was pretty greasy, but it's a good cheat meal.  My bf had the lamb something or other, the one with the polenta on the bottom.  I tried some of his and it was excellent!

If we weren't too full, we would have tried the dessert here, as I see tons of people raving about it. 

I would definitely revist this place.  It is small, so I'm sure a reservation would be a wise choice especially at a normal lunch hour.
author: Ghizal A.

description:
Came here for lunch on Valentines Day.. had reservations which was definitely the smart thing to do. All time slots were taken except 1130 and 130 and even at 1130 the restaurant got packed right away.

I had been looking forward to the truffle fries so I ordered those right away along with the Bucatini. 

These truffle fries just about broke my heart on this fine day of love. After spending about 5 minutes smelling them and thinking there is NO truffle oil on these fries, I asked a waiter walking by if these were indeed truffle fries and he assured me they were. Still a little skeptical I found another waiter for a second opinion. This is where he clarified that it's truffle AIOLI.  

My bad for not reading the menu clearly, but these SUCKED. The aioli was 99.9% mayo with a teensy bit of truffle oil, and they definitely presqueeze these bad boys out because our aioli had already grown a skin on it.

Bucatini was really good. Perfectly chewy and al dente, the way I love it.

The decor and stuff is nice and trendy. But why would anyone invent truffle aioli!! Disgusting.
author: Angela L.

description: Really tasty food beautifully created and creatively presented.  Warm and gracious wait staff.  Beautiful warm environment (we ate upstairs).  I'll be back!  Thanks for a wonderful dinner!
author: Steve W.

description:
ATMOSPHERE: Excellent. You come here for the atmosphere. Its beautiful in this restaurant and its a great place to sit down and relax. 

FOOD: OH MY GOD. I have never experienced food THIS bad. My husband and I came for dinner. We first ordered the Crispy Pork Belly appetizer. When it was placed in front of us we both looked at it in terror. IT IS LITERALLY a huge piece of pig stomach slapped on a plate.  I took a bite and was immediately horrified. Gelatinous, grease with a little meat and horrible flavor. THERE WAS NOTHING CRISPY ABOUT IT! My main course was Lamb Sugo. HORRIBLE. No flavor, and the lamb was nothing but greasy bites of pure fat, not meat. My husband ordered the Peppered Encrusted Flatiron steak and let me just say that I had one bite and my first response was: "IT tastes like eggs!!" My husband scrunched up his nose and said: "I was wondering why it tasted so awful. Your right!" 

We both left feeling extremely disappointed in spending a ton of money on horrible meals. Needless to say if I was to go here again it would ONLY be for a glass of wine and a quiet chat. 

The food was THE WORST I have ever experienced.
author: D. S.

description:
This is right around the corner from our office & has a great vibe so we stop in quite a bit. The staff is solid and we love the daily flatbread, the burrata and the brussels sprouts.

Sit at the bar if you get the chance--Arnie and Alexa are pretty awesome. Also happy hour is pretty good if you can make it in time!
author: Sam P.

description:
Hidden jem in the Fidi. The restie is pretty hidden, but definitely one of my favs places and be able to get a table!  Cute decor, great cocktails/wine, and delicious food!

For a girl that doesn't usually crave pastas, this place has great pasta.  Most of the ones I've tried here were really good. Reasonable prices too! 

My must have dish is the bucatini with pork ragu-- so delish!!! 
Another must try was buratta toast- simple, but so delicious!
author: Lorraine W.

description: Love ! Such a classy environment and the staff is impeccable  . A breath of fresh air from working on market and needing to breath . People come here to relax and enjoy not get drunk . Love !
author: Jessica M.

description:
Great lunch menu with generous portions but the service is well... a little weird.

Found this place on opentable for lunch and decided to give it a shot.  I checked out their menu online and saw that they had cioppino.  I then cross referenced the restaurant on yelp to make sure the opentable reviews were not BS and even went to the length of typing cioppino into yelp's search feature within the restaurant review.  Score! Based on the other Yelper reviews, the cioppino here sounds like a winner.

We arrived at the restaurant and were promptly seated upstairs.  The server greeted us shortly after being seated and took our drink orders.  We both said that water would be fine, Thanks. The server says "two ice tea's coming right up" and darts off. No, wait.. we didn't order ice tea, I shouted.  Oh.. no ice tea?  Nope. Later as the server was taking our order, we asked him how big the salads are and if it's big enough to share. Not giving us a description, he puts down his writing tablet and says it's about that size.  Um.. do you mean the plate or the portion because your tablet is flat. The server couldn't really explain so we just took our chance and ordered the caeser salad to share. Turns out the portion is quite generous and perfect for sharing. The salad was quite tasty but doused with way too much dressing which left the leaves a bit soggy.  The dried garlic was a really nice touch though.  Next time, I'll order the dressing on the side.

When the cioppino arrived, I was quite satisfied with the portion size and amount of seafood.  To my surprise, cioppino was kind of spicy which was not indicated on the menu.  I eat a lot spice so if I can taste it, it might be too spicy for people who can't handle spice.  The ciopinno tasted delicious but I was disappointed that they didn't give me a spoon to eat it with. Trying to hunt someone down was next to impossible so I ended up eating the entire thing with my fork.  What I couldn't pick up with the fork, I dipped my bread into.  Overall, good food and a nice place to lunch.
author: Wina K.

description: This is a great place to grab lunch, happy hour, or dinner. There is always a good crowd and the service is top notch. Ask for Bree or Abe, and they will give you a great experience, and leave you satisfied and wanting to visit again. Over all a beautiful restaurant with awesome food. I will visit again soon!
author: Trenton J.

description: Had an amazing dinner and girls night out at this restaurant tonight!  First time here and it blew my mind! We had the charcutire plate, duck and chicken. I especially loved the crispy asparagus appetizer! I have a bit of a pet peeve when a dish isn't salted enough, or is oversalted, so I absolutely love that this chef had everything seasoned to perfection! Met the manager Devin and he was more than welcoming and accommodating. Me and the girls will definitely be back again soon!! 5 stars without a doubt!
author: Megan K.

description:
Love the ambience - especially upstairs. It feels like you are in an estate home. Very intimate and cozy. Great for a relaxing dinner with friends or for business - you can actually hear each other. 

Service was very good. The food was 'okay' to 'good'. I didn't order the items I actually would have preferred because my friend has dietary issues and wanted to share. So I was careful and ordered probably the blandest items.... my preference is more interesting flavors....

Definitely will go back and try some of the more enticing (to me) items on the menu. 

Shout out to management!!! My friend left a folder behind and I got a call within an hour letting us know and told that it would be kept safe until we picked it up. Unexpected professionalism and courtesy! Extra star just for that experience alone.
author: Ping P.

description: I had a great dinner here with one of my friends. The food was outstanding and the service was great. I would certainly eat here again when I'm in town.
author: Michael M.

description:
Just an FYI to whoever is looking at their menu online, that some things will not be on the menu when you physically eat here.  Some ingredients will change, and some dishes will simply not be on the menu.  I was looking forward to trying their Funghi pizza with roasted wild mushrooms, shallot-thyme duxelle, shaved Grana Padano, Sherry vinager, fines herbs, and truffle oil, but they did not have it.  Instead, I ordered the potato bianca pizza which had pancetta and potatoes.  I was skeptical, but the pizza dough was very good.  The pancetta was very crispy, and went very well with the potatoes and white sauce.  The GF ordered the Bucatini pasta.  Apparently the pasta is made fresh.  I tasted it, and was quite impressed.  I have never tasted pasta like that.  

Parking was fairly easy for a weeknight since there were empty street parking spots around the entire block.    The decor is modern and they try to make it look sophisticated.  The chairs are mighty comfortable.
author: Victor L.

description:
Wow!  I think I just experienced the dumbest waiter in the world.  He couldn't get anything right.  First, he mumbled and was inarticulate, so I had to ask him to repeat more than 1/2 of what came out of his mouth!  Anyway, in what should have been a sign of things to come:  When my friend said Kir Royale, his mind heard something called a ******maker.  Then, when he brought this erroneous *****maker, we told him the order was Kir Royale, and he asked if we wanted it neat or on the rocks.  Huh?!?!?  We didn't even know how to respond.

Then, he "coursed" our meal in a really bizarre way.  For 3 people, we ordered a pizza, 2 salads, the Tagliatelle with a medley of veggies pasta dish, and the Bucatini which was some thick spaghetti'ish pasta soaked in a delicious pork ragu, with four, yes just four, shavings of pecorino.  The Tagliatelle had a slightly spicy kick that made what could have been a boring vegetarian pasta tasty.  The pizza was mediocre.  Not sure about the salads since I didn't have any.  

Anyway, back to the story of subpar service, we confirmed to Mr. Waiterman that the pizza and Tagliatelle would be shared, and he decided that meant to serve the pizza and Tagliatelle as the "first course," then to serve the salads and the Bucatini as the "second course."  Maybe it's just us, but we thought it made more sense to serve the pizza and salads as firsts, then the pastas as seconds.  The worst part about the weird "coursing" was it meant we had to wait 30 minutes between our "first" and "second" course.  Mind you, this is after waiting 20ish minutes for drinks.

Of course, he had to top it off by charging us for items we didn't have, which took more of our time to correct the bill.

Despite the maybe slightly above average food, the crappy service just about ruined it, bringing what could have been a 4 star rating to 2.  Per Diem isn't a cheap eat, so if I'm paying those kinds of prices, I expect a certain standard of service.  I definitely didn't get it, and I'm not sure I'd go back to be subject to such subpar service again, even if they comp'ed our dessert.
author: Christina L.

description:
Dinner for 1.

- Ambiance (3/5)
A bit of a rustic charm.  

- Service (4/5)
Courteous and very quick.  Water constantly refilled.

- Bread (N/A)
A bit surprising not to have any bread.  

- Cup of White Bean / Bacon Soup, $4 (2/5)
A bit under-seasoned and a bit of a strange goopy texture.  The elements just didn't meld together.  

- Tagliatelle, $17 (2/5)
California pasta strikes again.  Tragic.  The pasta wasn't al dente and the sauce was a bit too salty.  It overwhelmed the pasta.  The meat was oh so tender, but it really couldn't save the dish.  

- Gelato, $7 (2/5)
I found it a bit strange that for the "gelato sampler", I was served 2 sorbets and 1 ice cream, and no gelato.  For what they were, they were decent.  The raspberry sorbet was appropriately tart.  The ginger/pear sorbet had a hefty ginger flavor.  And the vanilla ice cream was delicious.  But, I wanted gelato.  

- Value (4/5)
You can good portion sizes, especially on the soup.  

- Final Word
The good value just doesn't overtake the poor execution on dishes.  Things either aren't what they seem or have some unappetizing elements.
author: Jeff J.

description:
Per Diem is a serious place. I mean, you just walk in and start feeling serious once you see the dark wood everywhere, vintage hardbound books and other old-timey props. For some reason I don't really think of 'serious' and 'lunch' together, so when I brought a group of my coworkers there on our lunch break it was kind of jarring, but I think it probably works better for dinner. It felt even more serious once they led us into their upstairs area for our reservation, and sat us at a huge, serious table that was probably a bit too large for our party of 5. 

In any case, the food we had for lunch was excellent so I could really lighten up and look past all of the seriousness. After much hemming and hawing I went with their oyster po'boy, which was very simply dressed but super tasty. I loved the fresh taste of the sourdough bread and the relish they used. All of the selections I saw come out looked excellent, especially the pasta choices. The prices are expected for a nice place like this in the financial district - about $13 for my sandwich. Not the best value on earth, but I think the ambiance and great service make it worthwhile, especially if you're looking to impress colleagues at a lunch meeting. 

Overall highly recommended!
author: Christina P.

description:
I'm a big fan of Per Diem because during a delicious lunch I can sit around an old backgammon table in what seems like a nautical library and talk big business with my man friends over a stiff cocktail. Ok well mostly we talk about youtube clips and the latest episode of Community, but whatever, we can pretend.

The dungeness crab melt is killer and my companions enjoy the burger. Last time we came we had a cheese plate and it was delightful. They've got some great beers and a Pimms Cup on the menu, so truly Per Diem has my heart for financial district lunch spots.

Bonus: They have tiny but perfect outdoor patio upstairs!
author: Nikki M.

description: Pretty little spot to escape the madness of the Financial District.
author: Patrick S.

description:
This place might as well be called "So, you need a place to have a nice business lunch.."...but really. It's PERFECT for a business lunch. 

We got the bread sampler and fries to share at the table. Fries are your average skinny fries, very good, and the bread came with about 5 different types of breads, plus dipping sauces. I got the Caesar salad...very tasty, fresh, but heavily seasoned. 

Others in the group got sandwiches, which looked really good. 

The decor is definitely my fav though, it looks like some old fancy man's home office from some 1900s parlor on the Upper East Side.
author: Molly S.

description: Went in with my girlfriend on Tuesday for an early dinner. We were greeted by the manager Devin right as we walked in. The bar was full (always a good sign) and taken to an awesome table upstairs. Our server Lux was great from beginning to end. We never felt without. All our courses were stellar and Devin even came upstairs to check on us twice! We will be returning!
author: Mario F.

description:
God.  When I walked into Per Diem, I had these lustful feelings. 

Towards the exposed concrete. 

The alluring chandelier. 

The grand Venetian like painting.

We strolled in here at 10pm after a romantic dinner and I'm glad I brought my A game.  With Per Diem's location in the Fidi, you should expect a well-dressed crowd for happy hour, but I guess that's also true for late night. 

The cocktail menu is short but seeing top shelf alcohol and housemade bitters gives me good vibes about it.  The Dividend cocktail was made with 10 Cane rum, chartreuse verte, luxardo maraschino and lime juice. Chartreuse tends to be really herbaceous but this drink actually takes on a refreshing taste thanks to the lime juice. 

Their Blood and Sand was mixed with scotch, carpano antica, house infused cherry brandy and OJ. It was heavy on the scotch, but I actually prefer a bit more vermouth.  

The atmosphere borders on the traditional but cozy. Lots of dark wood, steel beams and large pillars. Cocktails aren't cheap being $13 each, so I wouldn't make this a place to get wasted. However, put this on your radar if you want a classy crowd where you can sip your cocktail slowly and enjoy the jazz music in the background.
author: Janice C.

description:
First, I have to take my hat off to Hops and Hominy. I had set up a reservation at H&H for lunch with a colleague for a Friday in December. 2 days later I got a cancel message. Turns out they had a buyout (that time of year, I guess). I was perturbed, but more because I'd have to start my search all over again and don't get to SF often. Well when I was talking to the mgr at H&H she offered a recommendation and that was...Per Diem. Love, love, love that confident, customer centric approach. I will absolutely look up H&H next time I'm in town.

So at Per Diem, the place has this really funky style that just works. Total heavy wood motif with 19th century faux-gaud artwork and antiques placed throughout - totally works. 

I had the Cioppino (it was cold and rainy and that felt right) and my friend had the Ravioli. We both loved, loved our lunch. I had a Tempranillo by the glass that paired perfectly with the Cioppino. The Cioppino was spiced aggressively but in my opinion, perfectly. My friends Ravioli was smooth and tasty and, before I could blink, disappeared from site.

I'll be back!
author: Bill B.

description:
I went to Per Diem for a drink the week that it opened and found it to be a cool little spot for happy hour. The decorations are fun and interesting. Today, I decided I want to try this place for lunch. I found that Per Diem lacks decent hospitality. The two front desk people were more interested in giggling at each other than asking me if I had any questions regarding the menu. That's not the issue though.

After briefly looking over the menu, I picked the chicken sandwich with the heirloom tomato soup. The wait wasn't bad for my to-go order. I work super close to this restaurant so as soon as I got my food, I was back in the office. It was so disappointing to find that the heirloom tomato soup was lukewarm and, for the most part, unappetizing. Seller's Market has better tomato soup. Also, when I tried the sandwich, the bottom was soggy. 

Overall, maybe I didn't get the right sandwich or Per Diem serves hot soup only if you eat at the restaurant, but I'm disappointed. The bill was $16 - I should have went to Chipotle a couple times instead.
author: Irina R.

description:
I love this place. The menu was recently revamped, and while the food was always good, now it's amazing. The mixed drinks are always done well and the beer and wines lists are really good. It can get busy, especially on Friday during happy hour (this is the financial district after all), but it's often quiet and easy to get a table outside of the expected busy times. 

There aren't many places in SF I've been to more than once, since there's always a new place to try, but Per Diem has become a definite favorite and a stand by whenever we want to go someplace we just KNOW will be good.
author: Courtney W.

description:
This was the kind of place that I wanted to hate--I walked in and wanted to say that the decor was over the top and snooty but in fact it was really interesting w/o being overbearing. I wanted to say that service was distanced and cold but in fact our server was warm, suggested the perfect dishes, and appropriately attentive. I wanted to say that the food was overpriced and just OK but in fact it was very reasonably priced and delicious!

I really couldn't find anything wrong with per diem and I think it's a great place for dinner and a drink with friends in this part of the city w/o breaking the bank.

We had:
Crispy Pork Belly and Panzanella to start
Paparadelle and Mushroom Pizza
Panna Cotta and Gelati Trio

All were divine (except that gelato was already melting when it hit the table but I'll forgive that). Our waiter suggested the paparadelle and it was AMAZING! So good! I'll have to try to recreate it at home. The crispy pork belly also came in this really good corn soup broth that was so flavorful.

I will definitely be back! Perfection.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
My friends and I stopped by for dinner after a meeting in the city.  We were limited by distance around our hotel, but we were all pleasantly surprised by the decor, service, and food.

Per Diem easily accommodated our party of 9.  The decor is gorgeously "old world" chic with dark wood and paints, but not so uptight that you couldn't be comfortable in jeans.  I definitely see suits fiting in here.  The service was fast and the waiter was super friendly and helpful.

Our party wasn't super adventurous, so we stuck to the tried and true: buccatini with beef ragu, rabbit ravioli, and the seafood cioppino.  I recommend them exactly in that order.  I would order the buccatini again - perfectly al dente with an amazing beef sauce.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

Their pizzas also look good, as well as their drinks.  If only we didnt' have "work" to do.  If I lived/worked in the area - could definitely see myself coming back.
author: Vicki C.

description: Another great night with the best bar staff in the financial district. The gorgeous blonde (female) bartender who welcomed me into the bar was so engaging I stayed well past my intention. The staff is fantastic and the food and wine selection make it a great place to hang out and stay. After the happy hour people leave it just get better. Come and hang out.
author: Mr. B S.

description:
I'm definitely a fan of this place. I came for lunch with coworkers and though we had a reservation that was not met, we were squeezed into a table in the front of the house. The decor and ambiance of this place is beautiful: both light and airy. I didn't have a chance to visit the upstairs but, as far as the downstairs dining area and bar goes - it was pretty classy with a beautiful chandelier adorning the ceilings and a great wood bar.

The menu consisted of a variety of salads, sandwiches and reasonable priced entrees including pizzetas, pastas and a lasagna of the day. I went with sharing the crab melt and the ham and cheese sandwiches that were both accompanied with side salads (there was an option to add fries or soup for a couple extra bucks). The crab melt wasn't my favorite. The sandwich was extremely rich with the super intense butter overpowering the crab. There was potentially cheddar or some type of cheese involved adding to the rich experience of flavors.  The ham and brie was a delicious sandwich that was light and full of flavor. I've always been part of the school that you can't go wrong with brie and this sandwich proved me right. I love when that happens.

The service was great and overall this was a great lunch break that both left me satisfied and happy. I would most definitely come again and look to try one of thouse gourmet pizzettas.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
(See pics) Review #1119. A drinking place with pretty good house made pasta.

Downstairs there were a handful tables catering larger groups of 5 for dinner and a bigger space for the Fidi named drinks.

But I came here for dinner upstairs, which was at quite a different pace. You leave the noisy Fidi crowd who looks more like fresh grad first job crew, to a more secluded upstairs dinner only space. It was all table seating and the upstairs bar currently is used for keeping glasses but there maybe some planning to make it a standing drinking area as well.

Nopat (Bulleit Rye, Coeur de Lion Calvados, Punt e Mes, Benedictine, Bar Keep baked apple bitters) was good solid and not watered down. 

Look beyond the drinks was the semi-bar style appetizers and I had the burrata (misspelled on menu) with honey and almond flakes. It was good but nothing too impressive.

On the dinner side, they have 5 entrees, 5 pastas, 3 lasagnas and 3 pizzas. Since they proclaimed it's an Italian and Californian (Italian name but really more Californian style) with house made pasta, I had Orecchiette Puttanesca (also misspelled on menu.) It was spicy on the subtle, with lots of prawns, anchovy sauce, cherry tomatoes and small sized capers. It was quite tasty,

They currently don't serve desserts as they are still working on expanding their dinner menu such as Artic char and duck confit, The funny server did suggest a martini as desserts.

Half way through they decided to turn on the lights on the outside and wow my 
eyes lit up! It's a nice patio! It's small but very pretty with a chandelier. The outside ladder had a library lookalike ladder but from where I sat it looked like a fire escape.

Apart from that the interior has some copied Van Gogh oil painting, with part of the back not yet utilized other than a couple chairs. Very classic and I totally dig it.

As noted, the service was on and off fast, as they apologized they had to serve both the people downstairs and the dinner patrons upstairs. Overall it was decent and very friendly service.
author: T L.

description: This is one of the most unique dining experiences in the city.  The atmosphere is incredible and the chef is brilliant!  Try the tempura asparagus and the duck!  The GM is so welcoming and the staff is super knowledgeable.  The bar manager has a great program  going and you can find some nice craft whiskeys on the shelf.  Definitely stop by for happy hour!
author: Kelly B.

description:
*********************** 713 **************************

       Love the decor, rustic looking, beautiful woods and the gorgeous chandelier, the upstairs lounge and the little outdoor garden for smokers!   Plenty of wines, and simple food. Reasonable price list! Heard that they are working on the Gluten Free menu! So my date was excited about it! 

       I've been here a few times now and it's always packed. Smack in the Financial District and downtown, convenient spot for me. Love it here, the manager Chris is wonderful and he's a sommelier, you can chat up with him about wines! Love the vibe here! My kind of wine bar!

        P.S. Can you serve flute for my Prossecco next time please!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: One of my new favorite places in the city.  I got to try per diem with my friend on a fun lunch out. Everything we ordered was delicious.  I can't wait to have a date night here with my husband. Wonderful atmosphere.  I love the rich leather and dark decor.  Chef Lionel's food is amazing!
author: Stacie V.

description:
-1 for sort of crappy pimms cup
+1 then -1 for the Bubble theory cocktail which while tasty brings on the hangover early and hard.

I do like how both the name of the bar and a lot of the cocktails are sort of tongue and cheek financial industry jokes but are sort of about the reasons why people resent the financial industry.
author: Misha T.

description:
This place was a fantastic find! The service is authentic, the food is high quality and creative but still familiar, and the setting is welcoming. 

Monica helped me and the Old Fashioned she made was superb. The massive furnace converted to a beer tap was a nice touch. 

No food this trip but everything coming out of the kitchen smelled great. Definitely coming back for dinner.
author: Alexander F.

description:
I really wanted to like Per Diem. It sounded pretty good so I made the decision to take my hipster co-worker there for his goodbye lunch today. First hiccup - our table wasn't ready until 15 minutes past our reservation time. Then we had a waiter who seemed to be having an off day (he didn't seem to get my question about whether there was dairy in one salad dressing on the menu, brought dishes at the wrong time, etc.). I'll go back, someday, but might wait awhile so that management has time to iron the kinks out of being a newly opened restaurant.

P.S. One of the three stars is just for the decor - it's pretty cool...
author: Erin W.

description: Updated menus - tried the Dungeness crab lasagna tonight. Excited to try all the new dishes. Scallop salad for lunch looks delish.
author: Chris T.

description: Good location in a deserted part of fidi, crowd not overly massive or techie, Food is ok but limited selection and pricey overall. I liked my server lady
author: Stephanie M.

description: Walked in and the host told me to sit myself where EVER I WANT, 3 different times when I was waiting for someone. I went to sit... After the bus boy (whatever he was)  told me and my friend that we needed to move and I said ( you guys just told me to sit where ever I want) he told me "you don't need to whine about it" I didn't want to say anything to the uneducated server after he's stupid remark. After we sat for 10 minutes with no menus he brings my table of 3 only two menus. (Strike two) then as we sit there for another 5 minutes he decides to share that the kitchen is closed. The girls were rude. And he was ridiculously rude. Would never go back here again. And the last time the food was horrible anyways.
author: Lexy D.

description:
The Pork Buccatini is my favorite.  Drool.

Very small location so fills up quickly, but is very comfortable space to have a meal or drinks.
author: J H.

description:
I have eaten here 5 times in 3yrs. The bad news, not ONCE have they got the whole meal right. Wrong food here, forgotten items there etc. The good news, not ONCE have I paid the full check. 

Management, you have a gorgeous place, please bring in some professionals to run the service.
author: Duncan L.

description:
Maybe it is because my belly is still full but I truly enjoyed my experience here.  Here the qualitative reasons I had fun:

The waitstaff and other patrons were all sweethearts. There was even a brony sighting!  I had to wait about 15 minutes for a table but the music and mood compensated for it.

I get the feeling I'd enjoy this place even if it were chock full of sourpusses. The decor is intriguing.  Feast your eyes on a whole lot of bare brick and canvas. Turn your gaze to the ceiling and try to make sense of the lighting.  I can certainly get the feeling that it was Mad Men era inspired. Please note: you can watch sports at the bar.

I dined solo so I decided to forgo an entreé:

Bone marrow was calling my name and had been for days.  I admit, I've had better but this was tasty and surprisingly plentiful. It made me wish my God-puppy, Jack, had been with mebecause these were some big ol' bones reminiscent of The Flintstones cartoon.

Burrata! I was not intrigued until I read all the reviews about it. I decided to give it a whirl and it was lovely. In fact, it was heavenly with its melody of flavors and cloud like appearance.

To be a good girl I ordered vegetables - yellow & green beans! I would pair this with the bone marrow again. Their preparation was savory and salty and lovely.


I plan to return. Given the wait on a Wednesday evening after seven you bet I'll be back midweek. I'll wager it is packed on weekend evenings.
author: Joanna B.

description: This place is really good. Good drinks, ambience, and staff. Guy with gold teeth and pony tail was awesome :)
author: Stefani O.

description:
I'm surprised with so many negative comments on Yelp about the poor service and portions Per Diem management has not made any improvements... Needless to say I did not check Yelp before going here, happen to be hungry and walking by the restaurant after a long day of shopping in downtown and we decided to just go in! NOT IMPRESSED and won't be going back! 

Food flavors were just OK but definitely small dinner portions in comparison to the price and other comparable restaurants. 

Even though we each had a cream based cup of soup for starter we weren't really full after completely finishing our entrees... The soup was delicious! 

I ordered the pork chop special, it was a 1" thick small palm size cut (including the fat and bone) with literally 3-4 thin roasted carrot strips for $28. After cutting off the bone and fat trimmings I was left with a very small piece of meat and with no substantial side on the plate I was still hungry.

My husband got the pasta that the server recommended as their most popular dish and at $20 it was just a spaghetti bolognese with severely under cooked pasta and 30-40% smaller portion than the average comparable restaurant. 

I think the biggest disappointment was the service... Our server was very scattered minded, slow, and couldn't answer food related questions properly. I honestly think he was high... every time we wanted something or had questions I had to literally get up from the table and grab another server for assistance (happened 3-4 times) as he was no where to be found.... he didn't even check after the food arrived to see if we needed anything else. My husband wanted Parmesan for his pasta and 10 minutes after the food was served I had to once again get up to grab a bus boy....  VERY FRUSTRATING!!! 

The service pretty much ruined the dining experience and even though we weren't full we didn't want to stay longer to order dessert. 

It is tricky to label this place as moderate $$ range where in reality with their smaller portions you definitely spend $$$ range per person.
author: Shell S.

description: Great spot to check out for dinner! The ambiance and decor of this old building is simply stunning! The service was fantastic and the food and drinks were amazing! I made a reservation last minute for a large group and everyone left happy! I had the lamb which was superb. Overall very pleased and glad I stumbled upon this restaurant.
author: Sonya V.

description: Stopped in Per Diem for a drink with my boyfriend on the way to Bart. I've never been, but the atmosphere was great. The manager Devin greeted us right when we walked in and couldn't be more friendly. The cocktails were spot on and the bartender Abe made my boyfriend the best Manhattan he's ever had. I only wish we had showed up hungry because the food smelled and looked phenomenal. We'll definitely be back for dinner soon.
author: Monica R.

description:
Italian comfort food with a sexy twist!!!!!

The food: We had the  burrata on crostini with almonds, sea salt and honey, which the waiter recommended. Soooo good. Also the bucatini with pork ragu, another stand out dish.

The service: Super friendly and knowledgable about the food. Also, always checking in on us, making sure we had what we needed.  

The atmosphere: The downstairs is swank and cool, with a rustic opulence. But you can sit upstairs for a more intimate meal. Either place same great food!

Can't wait to go back.
author: Cary Elizabeth L.

description:
I chose Per Diem for a birthday dinner because the ambiance in the library room seemed really nice. Although I was happy with the decor, my praise ends there.
