Meatball appetizer was perfect; the sauce was rich and tasty. 
 They were 'out' of the bucatini, which we were so disappointed, but the lasagnette was a good alternative. 
Elegant, yet warm decor. 
Best Italian we have had on the west coast thus far.
author: Chris G.

description:
This place is flat out gorgeous and it's menu has the goods to match.

It's warm colors create an inviting ambiance while exposed concrete columns, and refurbished/reimagined pieces keep it edgy/Chic.  Now that they opened up the rest of the upstairs, there's a table for all types.  Downstairs has happening and louder bar feel, and upstairs has a quieter dining environment.

We've had a few different items here and it ranged from good to great.  The menu isn't an endless list of options, but the items that are available offer a variety that will suit all palates.  The dishes are well thought out, complex and delicious.

I'll be going back.  A lot.
author: Mike C.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city!  Perfect place for happy hour or dinner.  We started the meal with the PEI Mussels and an order of Burratta.  Both were on point and delicious.  I had the swordfish and it was light and buttery - perfectly cooked.  My BF the pork chop and it was out of this world.  

My parents are coming to town next week, so we'll be back again!
author: Samantha D.

description: We ordered appetizers, entrée and desert, they are all VERY good. Located conveniently in the center of financial district with good déco and awesome food. Will definitely go again when I'm in the mood of a Fancy meal
author: Sophia S.

description: I was not impressed with the food at Per Diem, especially given the price. I had the burrata and chicken flatbread and it was not great. First of all Burrata is meant to be eaten a certain way and melting it into oblivion on a soggy flatbread is just not OK. Then, the chicken was these tiny pieces of chopped chicken which was pretty disappointing. For $17, I expect a delicious flatbread given the inexpensive nature of the ingredients.
author: Donna L.

description:
I would say it's a 3.5

Had lunch there yesterday, it's a nice place. A few tables along the walls with a couple being booth & high tables. Sat at the bar, friendly and good staff.  Food selection was decent, order the crab melt. Was nice came with a side salad, which is nice, but for a $14 sando, it better come with something.  The sando seemed to have more roasted tomatoes then actual crab and unfortunately the bottom of the sando got really soggy. The top had a nice crisp to it, wish both sides were like that. Will probably return, but no rush.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Per Diem is going to be dangerous for my wallet (or my bosses'....)
Since it has opened my boss, coworker and I have been three times already. Considering its NEXT TO our building, how could we resist?

They make a mean Pimm's Cup. 
For lunch, they have a variety of options ranging from salads and sandwiches to more substantial lasagnas and pastas. I like their tuna salad!
author: Sara P.

description:
Mid-week dinner for 3 was OK, but not particularly good or memorable.

Halibut special for the evening was small in portion, overcooked and under seasoned.  Truffle for the corn accompaniment seems to have been an idea only, not actually there.  Lasagnette was missing the tomatoes identified in the description.  Kitchen was out of pork for the ragu.  Crostada wasn't fully baked.  Made us wonder how long it had been since the chef had actually been present.  Service was inconsistent.

Would come back if someone else was buying, but wouldn't seek it out.
author: K T.

description:
Per Diem is a great place for a nice lunch that isn't going to drain your wallet. I highly recommend making reservations if you don't want to wait for a long time.  I ate the crab melt which was quite tasty, while my colleagues enjoyed a couple of their pizzas.

All around, I'd go again - in fact, I recommended it to my boss last week and he took a potential client. Both loved it. 

Keep it up, Per Diem!
author: Noneya B.

description:
Wish I could give this place 1.5 stars...

Dined there with my wife tonight. Started with the gulf shrimp cocktail ($15 bucks wasted) which did not taste fresh and required the lemon for sure.  Also had the organic salad which was the best part of the entire meal.

For entrees I ordered the special, which was halibut over some fancy mash potatoes and she had the tagliatelle pasta.  The funny thing about her pasta was that it claimed to have mussels and and it ended it having pork belly, sweet corn, tomatoes etc.  Needless to say, her's was underwhelming... better to stick with a jar of pasta sauce from home.  

The halibut cost $23.  I expected about $25 but I also expected the a good slice of Halibut.  It was thin, overcooked, had bones and was over-powered by the fancy mash potatoes.

Thought we were going to get dessert but couldn't understand a single word on the dessert menu except for chocolate so we decided to pass on that portion and head home to an ice cream bar.

It gets points for being reasonably priced in the city -- its relative of course since the meal still cost us $80 bucks with tip.  Too many other good restaurants to come back to this one.
author: Mr. E.

description:
Per Diem got a lot of buzz when it first opened, but I've been three times over the past year and every time I've been somewhat disappointed.  If you're going for drinks, it's a fun place for a few people.  

Per Diem is not a place for larger crowds.  We were sat upstairs for a business lunch of 7 people. They squeezed us into a table with 3 chairs on one side and a bench with no back for us 4 on the other side, and we were all touching elbows.  Not comfortable when you're on a business lunch.  

The first time I had lunch there, I had their lasagna which is their signature dish and it was REALLY oily.  It is really healthy and doesn't have the "fresh" yummy ingredients that SF has to offer.  It's mostly cheese and sauce.  The second time I went, I wanted something more on the healthy side, which they really don't have on their menu.  So I ordered a salad and asked them to add chicken.  The serving size of the salad was perfect (small, but just what I wanted) but the chicken was really salty and nothing special... and then the salad was just eh.

Sorry, Per Diem.  I really want to give a better review, but it's just not there yet in my opinion.  Always willing to try again in 6 months :)
author: Dara S.

description: Umami excellence! I had the evening's special, steak frites, and it was delightfully flavorful. To start, the quality of the meat was top notch; tender and cooked to specification (more rare than medium rare). Coated with porcini dust, as well as other spices, the added flavors were intense, but welcome! Not for the faint of heart, but a treat on special occasions. The frite accompaniment conjured images of McDonald's fries (which are among my favorite), with a more refined touch. Out doing them all, though, was the oyster infused aoli - what an excellent accent to both the steak and the frites!
author: Justin P.

description:
To save you from holding your breath - I'm giving 4 stars for now until the 2nd floor opens... in which, I'm looking forward to providing my 5th. 

Ok, let's start. Read about Per Diem through the various SF blogs and was amp'ed to check out what all the fuss was about. And let's just say, if you hang out at a restaurant bar for 4-5 hours on a Friday afternoon, you're probably having a pretty damn good time and so it was on 12/30/11. Trickled in for lunch on a Friday afternoon, found a couple seats at the bar as the rest of the 1st floor tables were taken and what a great decision it was. Jake at the bar was kind enough to be the server helping us as we started off with a Four Roses Bourbon Manhattan and some Barbera wine....which we had a chance to taste before committing...who does that? Anyways, we ordered Mary's Chicken(roasted with potatoes) and the Brisket sando. Both were lovely - moist, juicy and flavorful.

What helped us stay for 4-5 hours? Awesome drinks by the likes of French 75's, negroni's, beer selection, Fortaleza tequila, jumbo-@$$ shrimp cocktails(reminded me of being at Mastro's in LA), this lil ricotta on toasted bread app, more French 75's, and solid service from Jake from Boston, Chris Parks and the entire team. 

The 2nd floor is yet to be open but I'm looking forward to heading back to Per Diem to see the "expansion", try everything else on the reasonably priced menu and awesome ambiance. Cheers to the "Cali Gold Rush-esque" corner of town, much needed to spread out the happy hour crowd as we could always use another outpost in FiDi. I can only recommended that you get there early enough to grab a seat at the bar....and spend your 4 hours drinking and eating until your liver and heart's content.
author: Jessica C.

description:
It would have been 4 stars for the food - had the bucatini (delicious with just a tiny kick), but I have to subtract 2 stars for the service.  

When I arrived early for our reservation, the hostesses said that I was the first to arrive (which I figured I would be) so I could wait - not, you can wait at the bar, you can be seated and wait at the table, just "you can wait."  Then they proceeded to chat among themselves as I perused the menu in front of them.

Then, our waitress seemed to forget about us as we waited for our friend.  Our friend arrived half an hour after we did and ordered later than we did; however, her salad arrived first.  She politely waited for our food to arrive, and when it didn't after a good 10 minutes, she flagged down our waitress to make sure she understood that the salad was her entree and that she should serve our food soon too.  The waitress said it would be out soon - then after another 15 minutes we flagged her down again and she finally apologized that there was an error.

She told us it would be on the house, but we weren't sure if she just meant 2 of the entrees so we waited and waited for the check (which I usually get even if the meal is comp'd).  We had to flag down our waitress again for the check, to which she said that there wouldn't be one because it was on the house.  That is fine (and a nice gesture), but it would have been nice if she had told us there would be no check so that our now 2-hour lunch wouldn't have lasted even longer.
author: B. Y.

description:
Food: 4/5 - Fresh homemade pasta and Italian dishes - the asparagus/egg pizzete, bucatini ragu, and lasagnette were all well done. Though, doing a side by side comparison I'd say it falls just short (but close) to the quality/flavor at Barbacco down the way or Delfina. But if like either of the latter, this is a good spot to try.

Service: 4/5 - Good service, pretty prompt, and friendly. Nothing stand out but still took care of us.

Ambiance: 5/5 - Feels like a mix between Barbacco and Wayfare Tavern - hip and lively, but with old-school feel and decor. It's two stories, so there's a lot of space and so far doesn't seem to be too packed, and definitely was not loud when I went.

Value: 4/5 - It's still a good deal for pastas, at $12-15, but the pizzetas and salads are also ~$10-14, so it's a little more if you were to order a starter+pasta. Entrees are $20-24, though I haven't tried those.
author: Kevin T.

description:
I like this place, and would most certainly return.

A lovely, well-composed menu, charming decor. and attentive and friendly service. Requisite criteria for a four-star rated establishment in my book? Absolutely.

Let's start with the menu: fabulous salads -- I really enjoyed my pear/blue cheese salad, as well as innovative sandwiches, entrées, pizzettes, etc. (I so wanted to dive in to that asparagus soup, but didn't... still kicking myself for it!)

Seemed somewhat popular for lunch... we had a reservation and ended up in a sort of strange configuration at a random corner table, but I'm not paying that mind. I thought the whole lunch lovely and I'm definitely a fan of this spot.
author: Rachel F.

description: Very chic!!!!  Great place to have lunch or dinner with a friend or date.  Service was top notch, the food was delicious, and price was very reasonable.  Doesn't hurt that it was a block away from work.
author: Mike M.

description: We were looking for casual --  ie a bar feel with good food. Per diem really hit the spot!  Great food in wood booths.
author: M H.

description:
Not sure when this place popped up, but it's a short walk from my office, which is always a plus. 

swung by for dinner last night.  Their menu isn't very extensive, but that actually turns out to be a good thing, since it's quite easy to make a decisions.  i got the steamed mussels in sausage and fennel broth.  It was only $12 and there were at least 30 mussels in there, and the broth was amazing!  

i also ordered a bread and tapenade/cheese plate for $3, which was a really nice appetizer and came with plenty of warm bread.  

Overall, I think the prices here are really reasonable for SF and I'm certainly going to come back and try out more things on their menu.
author: Ash T.

description: Let me star by saying the food was excellent. I had the Cioppino, it was so rich in flavor and it had a  great selection of great quality seafood like crab, mussels, calamari, shrimp. It was DELICIOUS. I also had the oysters and again very good. The service was amazing as well , I had a server named Alex. He was very attentive, knew the menu from top to bottom and gave great selections of food and his knowledge of wine was impressive. He took great care of me and my friend. This is definitely a place I would visit again for sure. The food and service was amazing =)
author: Jocelyn R.

description:
Delicious and skillfully executed cuisine in a comfortable and trendy atmosphere.  By far the highlight of my meal was the perfectly tender bucatini served beneath a generous layer of pork ragu, which featured a well-rounded combination of tangy, savory, and spicy flavors, and a complement of shaved pecorino and basil leaves.  My fellow diners raved about the delicately decadent burrata on a grilled crostone, which was both light and satisfying.  On the other hand, the salumi platter (proscuitto, sopressata, coppa, salami, olives, cornichons) was a bit uneven, and -- due to the absence of starch with the order -- had to be supplemented with "bread service" (at a nominal fee of $3; hopefully not per person, but I don't recall).   

The service during our late lunch (i.e., 1:15 pm reservation) was courteous, responsive, and prompt.  Lastly, the menu was surprisingly inexpensive for the quality of food.
author: Chris T.

description: Went for lunch. Ambiance was lovely, but the waitress looked like she had just rolled out of bed. I wasn't really feeling adventurous, so I got the Caesar salad. It was small and had too much dressing on it, making the greens absolutely wilted. The chicken was tender, but cold and a little over-cooks for my liking. On a simple but expensive dish, I was pretty disappointed. Oh well, I just won't go again.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Urgh. I came here for a friend's birthday and we got to sit at the top. I do have to admit that the decor is really beautiful. However, I just felt like we had mediocre service the whole time. Also, we had a party of like, 12 people, and it was so weird to me how they gave us 2 separate tables to sit at instead of pushing them together.

I ordered the Paparadelle, and I was seriously underwhelmed. It just didn't really taste like anything. The noodles were extremely chewy though.
author: Melody L.

description:
The interior of Per Diem looked like what the set of a Pirates of the Caribbean movie would look like if it was built using only reclaimed materials from a Super 8 Motel.  

The Panzanella salad was a nice start, but could hardly prepare me for the groin-grabbingly transcendent Bucatini (you might want to protect your groin from the Cioppino, though).
author: Nobody M.

description:
I have gone here for lunch and dinner- both were excellent.

For lunch I had the dungeness crab melt and a beer. A bit indulgent for lunch, but damn was it good. The melty, white cheddar and tasty crab between buttery, toasted slices of bread was delicious.   

The ambiance upstairs is ideal for dinner, if you can get up there take it. I had the special. It was a white fish (I can't remember which one..) on a bed of mashed potatoes topped with asparagus and white wine sauce . It was unreal.

You will need to make a reservation for lunch or dinner, easily done through Open Table.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Went to Per Diem last night with the hubby and another couple. Place had a cool vibe, service was really great and the food was better than average. 

We ordered the burrata appetizer and it was to die for, drenched in honey and topped with slivered almonds... Definitely a 5 star... UHHHH MAYYYY ZING! If you go there and don't get it, I am seriously sad for you.

Had short rib ... I'd give that 3 stars... wasn't as flavorful as I would have hoped. 

Hubby had the Bucatini... give that 3.5 stars. Yummy pasta for sure and ragu was delish, but just slightly above average.

Our friends had the cioppino... I didn't have any but they said it was good and spicy

Overall... I'd give it a 4, but not a place I would die to go back to for dinner with so many other options in SF. I would DEFINITELY go back for drinks and apps. I could live in that burrata.
author: Amy Y.

description: Really nice nautical ambiance. Really really good pasta dishes - decadent, tasty, and a bit spicy: bucatini and lasagnette. So yummy. The pasta tasted fresh and was a perfect al dente.
author: Andrew K.

description: I'm not sure I understand why so many folks come here. There are amazing options not far at all from where this places. The food is only okay, but it's still okay.
author: Soo S.

description: Super cute ambiance, nice servers, traditional menu w/ eclectic twists.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Per Diem is my company's go to spot, and the friendly staff always make sure we are set up with a great table on our weekly visits. It has a bustling vibe and gets crowded around 5:30/6, but there is always room to sit and have a conversation, even with a bigger group.
-The atmosphere is reminiscent of an old school private club
-Our servers are always very courteous and professional
-The cocktails are perfect and there is a great wine list
-The food is stellar: I recommend the meatballs, pork belly, burrata toast, and the papardelle pasta
-There is a nice new happy hour with drinks and appetizer specials all around $6
author: Zach R.

description:
Love this place! 

Great interior, awesome atmosphere & tasty bits. Went with the brisket lasagna, and I gotta say, it tasted even better than those two words could sound combined in the same sentence.
author: Sean D.

description: Everything was good.  Nothing was great.  I liked the pork belly and the bone Marrow.  Had the Lamb Sugo as my main.  I cant believe I'm saying this because I love butter but it had too much butter.  How that is possible IDK?
author: Alexander L.

description:
Growing pains?

My friends and I came in here on a Tuesday night and inquired on our 8:30 reservation - the nice girl at the front said, "I have no more reservations but I can get you a table". So we waited at the bar and marveled at the decor. No biggie.

They seated us near the bar area which is fine. The drinks menu is very creative - they have "old money drinks" and "new money drinks" with names like Dividends or Bubble Theory. Pretty cool. As we ordered our drinks, we perused the simple and very promising menu. 

We waited a while for our drinks and ordered our meal - burratta, 6 oysters, salads (dressing on the side), pasta and duck. 

The first round of food showed up - the pasta and... a pizza?? Whups, guess they brought us the wrong order. My friend's salad arrived as well with dressing mixed right in and my oysters were nowhere to be seen. We flagged down someone for the oysters and he gave us a funny look and asked - "You want your oysters NOW?"

As we were eating our oysters and my friend was enjoying her salad, suddenly ALL our entrees showed up all at once - my duck, the pasta and my other friend's salad, which was not big enough to be an entree per what the waitress said. Our table wasn't big enough to accommodate everything. 

My duck was delicious - the broth, the bleu cheese ravioli, the mushrooms - everything came together. If I wasn't so annoyed at the service, this duck would have led me to come back for more.

While we were sitting there, my friend got a "no-show" notification on Open Table - given the woman at the front couldn't find our reservation, I'm not sure what went wrong there. 

The food was really good but I felt that the staff was underprepared and not particularly knowledgeable. I'm usually not a stickler for service but when it is noticeable it does really bother me. 

Not sure if I would go back for this. I'm hoping service improves as they become more established.
author: Karen K.

description:
No thank you.  When I asked my server to guide me to vegan options on the menu, he informed me that the restaurant does not serve vegans because the chef can't be bothered.  In actuality, there were vegan options on the menu, but between the incompetent server and arrogant chef, they didn't realize that they actually could accommodate me without doing anything special.  I was there for a business meeting, and the horrible service made things awkward.   Never again.

Plus, the food was not remarkable enough to even come close to justifying the chef's arrogance.  Nothing that a competent home cook can't handle.  (In addition, a truly competent chef is not scared to feed someone on a restrictive diet.  Per Diem has such an insecure, unimaginative kitchen staff.  Not worth it.)
author: Kat P.

description:
We arrived early for our reservation due to unusually good traffic on a stormy night. When we entered the restaurant we were told the restaurant was not yet opened. We asked if we could just sit and wait, out of the rain, until they were ready for us.  We were very rudely told no so we walked outside and waited 20 minutes until they opened the doors.
The decor was fun, warm and inviting and the waiter at our table was informed and very helpful.  We enjoyed the food but would not return because of the rude initial treatment.
author: Suzanne G.

description:
although i enjoyed just about every dish that i had at Per Diem....i wanted to express how MUCH I ENJOYED 1 specific dish...

call me simple...call me plain...

i never knew how FREAKING AMAZING a piece of hearty toast, covered in burratta, salt, honey, and almonds could be...

regardless of the succulent crispy pork belly dish...
regardless of the amazing lasagnette...
regardless of eating one of the tastiest meatballs I've ever had....

the simplicity of the Burrata on a Grilled Crostone and how these unassuming ingredients come together to create a masterpiece of an appetizer is truly hard to fathom without trying it yourself...

go try Per Diem...be impressed with their extensive wine and cocktail list...be impressed with their friendly staff...be impressed with the rest of their delicious menu...

BUT DO order at least 1 Burrata on a Grilled Crostone per person...maybe order 2 and make it a sandwich...the possibilities are endless...LOLOLOL
author: Kyu L.

description:
After my first visit to Per Diem, I would have given it four stars. I had a tasty mushroom pizza and fries with truffle aioli that I enjoyed. The only negative was that my food wasn't very hot, but it was good enough to make me want to go back. Unfortunately, on my second visit the food had the same temperature issues as before. Even more unfortunately, I liked the Papparadelle a lot less than the pizza.

I'd say Per Diem is a good lunch place if you plan to dine with someone who is impressed by prices. If you're going out with someone who cares about (warm) food, pass on this place.
author: Tazia M.

description:
I really didn't want to leave a review.
Not because the food is horrible, but I really didn't want to fight for seats.

Truffle aioli fries just makes my lunch that much better.
Their steamed mussels and assorted bread basket is a must. The bread is a meh, but to be able to dip your bread into that sauce?! Magnificant. 

Finding good place to eat in fidi is hard. Trying to do it on a budget is even harder... However, once in a blue moon when you get sick of your left over dinner for lunch, give Per Diem a try. Their decor is really awesome, their service can get little slow, but they're still smoothing out the rough edges.
author: S Y.

description: Solid place to go for a lunch meeting. The food isn't crazy and it's always fresh and tasty.
author: Angel S.

description: I come here for lunch cause they have a very nice fried oyster poboy. Quality of food is great with very professional staff
author: James T.

description: Went here twice for business lunch. The atmosphere is nice and intimate - perfect for a small party. Lighting can be a bit dim upstairs. There is not too many menu selections to choose from, which can make it easy as well as limited when picking what you want to eat. Their soups are pretty good and so is their lasagna :) Would come again!
author: Konnie H.

description:
Alright,  the house made Bucatini with spicy and tender pork ragu has forever changed my mind about Per Diem.   it was seriously the bomb !  Perfect texture of the bucatini, I was so pleased on a rainy cold Friday lunch after not eating breakfast and working all morning on an empty stomach. I don't get pasta very much anymore b/c it kicks off a serious sugar addiction and food coma, so when I do get it, I really want it to be the bomb and it surely lived up to its expectation of a spicy perfect ragu.  The Primitivo wine was excellent as well, and the bartender even gave me half  a glass, which was greatly appreciated.   The gelato was delicious, recommend the balsamic caramel.  

Only missing one start, b/c I was friendly with an ederly gentlemen at the bar sitting next to me as good neighbors can be, and was very surprised at the proposition I was presented with. 

Over all experience was great, and big kudos for the bartender, I am sorry, but I think the name was Barney(?).
author: Jenice A.

description:
Had lunch with an old friend today. We did not have reservations and were seated at a high top table across from the bar. The tables were seated very close together and it was sometimes a strain to hear each other.

The food was pretty good--nothing to write home about, but a nicer option than salad/sandwich shops to have close to my office. 

I would recommend that the management take the time to review their menu as I counted at least 7 typos (e.g., aioli/aoili, parmesan/parmeson) while I was waiting for my friend to arrive.
author: Mrs P.

description:
Per Diem is an awesome spot for an after work drink or longer lunch with the team or clients. It has an atmosphere that is conservative, yet trendy, and it's menu packs a punch. I consider myself to be quite a fan of food and some excellent foodie-grade cuisine can be found here, which includes the delicious bone marrow.

Overall, this is my happy hour go-to. The atmosphere allows you to feel comfortable in jeans or suit and tie - you could wear either and fit in perfectly. The drink prices are reasonable and the drink menu is creative. Check out the martinis and get your buzz on - its happy hour time!
author: I D.

description:
A Yelper below put it best: "I am rooting for this place" 

So why are they making it so hard for me to do so? 

Location, Location, Location: You have hit the jack pot! I work across the street, and our little pocket of the Financial District has been begging for an after-work watering hole for years! The best option we have right now is Sutter Station i.e. "Sutter Gutter", where the clientele is made up of primarily vagrants who are spending every last penny of their welfare checks on whiskey! Not really a "professional" environment so-to-speak. Basically, the market is wide open for Per Diem to flourish, but they need to improve their model. 

Couple suggestions for the owners:

*Go for the sports bar "Royal Exchange" vibe instead of the sheeshy wine bar  vibe. I was in their the other night and felt like I needed to lower my voice a few times. 

*Get flat screens lining the walls with sports games playing. This will bring more energy in general to the place.

*For the love of God, hire an architect that's worth a damn. Why is 20% of the space taken up by that obnoxious hosting table/waiting area in front? The place is already on the small side as it is!

*Cool down the Kegs. My IPA's were just barely above room temperature. And, when you take into consideration the paper thin glasses they are served in, one's beer gets WAY too warm WAY too quickly due to just holding it.... Also, you're not fooling anyone, no way those are 16 ounce pints!

Bottom line, check out what Royal Exchange, Irish Times, etc are doing and copy it. No need to reinvent the wheel (those places are far enough away that it's not necessary). 

All of that said, I truly am your biggest supporter. I want this to be me and my co-workers go-to spot. In fact, part of the reason I am writing this is because they are pressuring me to do so!

Best of luck as you continue to make this place better. 

~Coach K back and ready to rage (hopefully at Per Diem)
author: Coach K.

description:
I was delighted to find a gem like this one hidden in the otherwise often deserted downtown financial district. While most other reviews I see here don't talk about the food, mine will: Well cooked, satisfying, not too extraordinary, but I would come back for dinner another time.

I had the pappardelle pasta - great and generous portion, al dente pasta and hearty ingredients. If I weren't flying out that day I would have taken it with me.

Service was prompt and even with a 2-floor layout I felt it was attentive.
author: Shang S.

description: Went here on a Tuesday evening for dinner with a group of friends after work.  Place has a nice vibe and the bar was peopled with the after-work crowd.  Had one of their specialty cocktails, which was quite good.  Dinner was delicious and service was excellent and friendly.  I had the Bucatini, which was excellent.  It was served in a pork ragu all'arrabbiata.  Yum!  Everyone else seemed to thoroughly enjoy their entrees, as well.  Good go to place if you're eating Downtown.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Saw them on TV they were all booked for dinner on friday they saw us leaving and somehow made room.. excellent service and great place. The decor is really cool, and they have all of this comfortable chairs that are comfortably spaced so you feel like you are talking only with the people at your table and not making friends with the people next to you.  The food was also delicious, and everything we got seemed to get better and better (the best was the pesto pistachio pasta, which I also went back to get the next day).

Like other reviewers, my 5 stars is for the service.  Everyone was so friendly and went out of their way to be be nice and joke with us, but not in a "I'm getting involved in your conversation" type of way.  I'm so excited to go back, and hope to again soon.  I highly recommend it.
author: Johnny D.

description: Great vibe- with a colonial sort of theme... Food was fantastic- Brussels sprouts were crazy good - savory roasted jewels. Chicken was super tender and tasty- I was surprised that the chicken was so good.  Would definitely go back!
author: Cary S.

description: This was the first time I've been to Per Diem and I was immediately impressed with the staff and food. When first entering it can appear small, but the decorations and atmosphere felt elegant yet cozy. We had reservations at 1:30pm, but unfortunately our table wasn't ready. When it was, the Manager was kind enough to provide complimentary appetizer. Besides the service, the food was fantastic! My friends ordered the roasted chicken, a seafood medley dish, and I ordered a Poached Albacore Tuna Tartine sandwich for lunch. It did not look like a sandwich at all (see picture) but it was definitely delicious! It was a nice twist to eat a "sandwich" with a fork and knife. I'd definitely like to return here in the future to try their other delicious dishes!
author: Rj M.

description:
Had reservations for lunch and was seated promptly. The place filled up pretty quickly over the next 30 minutes. The restaurant is still relatively new (the space used to be a simple deli/salad bar type of restaurant). Nice remodel though and loved the vintage decor. Coat hooks by your table and underneath the bar counter were a great touch.

Tried:
Burata on a grilled crostene - Really good, but can be a bit heavy. Would order again.
Brisket sandwich - came with a side salad; good amount of brisket but bread was too filling
Crab melt - Preferred over the brisket

Nice, new alternative in the FiDi area for a sit-down lunch, that's not too pricey. Service was super attentive (waiter constantly made sure my Arnold Palmer was filled up). They have an interesting cocktails menu so I may have to stop by sometime after work to find out.
author: Rick T.

description:
Small, intimate, fun bar and restaurant in the financial district.  The crowd is mature or should I say sophisticated than your average bar goers. Lots of suits and ties. Average drink is around $12. 

I love the decor. Staff were very nice.
author: Sheila D.

description:
I rolled my eyes when I first saw Per Diem.  The unashamedly Yuppie name is nauseating, especially given its location in the downtown Financial District.  So I expected it to be douchebaggy, and thankfully it wasn't too bad. 

The owner was helping tend bar, and he acted like he cared about our business.  This was during their pretty busy happy hour, so i was impressed.  If you go at a more off hour, you can sit at the bar and marvel at the large, very Steampunk contraption in the middle of the bar.  I'm not even sure what it's for (brewing coffee?   pouring drinks?), but it is impressive and gives the place a bit more personality.  They also serve appetizer like bar foods, and I think you'll be okay as long as you don't go in expected French Laundry.
author: Dave N.

description:
My work decided to have lunch at this restaurant since it's near the office. We got to sit upstairs in the loft away, which was really nice. It was like we had a private area to ourselves. Yes, the food is pretty good. You must order the burata on grilled crostone for an appetizer! Yummy! I ordered Mary's Chicken and the chicken was nice and juicy. I thought the potatoes would have been better with some sea salt (but maybe that's just me - I like salt.) Our group then shared the two desserts they were offering at the time - panna cotta mouse and a pear tart/pie thing. Both were delish!

Aside from the food, my coworkers and I could not stop talking about the decorations. I mean I loved it, especially that piano on the wall, but we couldn't figure out the theme. Is it nautical? Greek? Vintage glam? We decided that the theme was eclectic. 

The place kind of reminds of Wayfare Tavern...

Either way, very cute restaurant. I'd come back again with friends. =)
author: Lorianne E.

description:
I liked Per Diem - lunch there is great!  Miss N. and I shared delicious burrata/honey/almonds on buttery toasted artisan bread and well seasoned broccoli rabe.  I enjoyed my chicken margherita sandwich which came with a well portioned and tasty green salad.  The restaurant is well decorated and spacious and could easily carry on a conversation.  I would be interested to see how the vibe changes from day to night.

Nice-ish spot for a casual business lunch without breaking the bank.
author: Aimee B.

description: Went for the first time a few months ago, was seated upstairs. Had an amazing meatball dish, and wonderful salad. Super attentive service, and it was quiet enough to conduct a business meeting. Went again a few weeks ago, seated downstairs. Crowded, not great service - food but no silverware, didn't check back often...probably because it was so busy. And, of course louder than upstairs. And, the meal wasn't as good - they'd changed the menu... I'll go back because it's so convenient to work, and I'd like to give it another try. Maybe they were having an off day...
author: Juliette M.

description: This place is great for happy hour. Wonderful selection of beer, wine and cocktails. The bar menu pairs wonderfully with the drink menu. The bartender grace was especially helpful and attentive. I'll be back!
author: brian c.

description: 3 stars for food (which is what I care about most), 5 for atmosphere.  Lovely setting for lunch (or, I imagine, for dinner, but that is not what we had).  But mediocre food: the minestrone was broth with some veggies and no flavor; I had the panzenela -- perhaps if their menu description had MENTIONED bread, I would have remembered the Italian word means mainly a bread salad, and not ordered it.  But bread wasn't even mentioned in the description.  My friend's roast chicken entree was fine, nothing special.  I wouldn't bother returning, maybe for a drink.
author: Robin W.

description: My wife and I were in town to visit a friend living in SF. We got in to town early and wanted to find a place to grab a drink while we waited for our friend to get off work and go out to dinner later. We found this small place Per Diem and was not that packed so headed over to the bar. Boy were we happy we stopped in. The drinks were on point, the appetizers were delicious, even though it was a little pricey (but then again, everything in SF is pricey!!) and the best part was our server BREE. Young beautiful girl with a great smile and made some great drink suggestions to us. For somebody that had not been there long, she really knew a lot about the menu and drink specials. I loved the "Manhattan Project" with the Whistle Pig 10yr Rye. We were only going to stick around for drinks, but when our friend got off work he met us there and we ended up having dinner there too. Turns out, this is one of his go to places and told us he was planning on bringing us here. I know there are many places in this area you can choose to eat, but once you find a place you like this, you want to go back. My wife and I will definitely be back again the next time we are back in SF. Go in and ask for Bree, she will take good care of you. Also, read some of the reviews for food from Per Diem, and I don't know what the old menu was like, but this new menu with new chef seems to be great. I couldn't decide what to order because every plate that was coming out looked delicious. I could have ordered everything.
author: Rigo B.

description: A great place for happy hour. Fun atmosphere, great food and drinks. Our server Wednesday night was excellent.
author: John B.

description: We were in last night and had a great time at the bar.  The bartender, Grace, was great.  The food was tasty and the drinks were perfect!  We will definitely be back.  Cheers!
author: Matt A.

description:
One of my best friends is a chef here but I am remaining as unbiased as possible, i promise!

First of all, let me say that this food is not what I would call my typical go-to favorite style of food.  I like to think of myself as a simple eater although my friends call me picky and a hard person to take out.  Oh well.

The atmosphere is super hip and cool; dim lights, upstairs loft seating with a bar and cool old fashioned books for decoration.  The drinks are great including specialty drinks that change frequently and a pretty good wine selection.  To start, we had the marrow which was a first for me and I did my best--it was peppery and buttery and I took a good faith bite like I promised I would.  I saw almost everyone around me order it, so I am sure that people who love marrow, love the dish.

For my main dish I ordered the king salmon and YUM was it good!  I am a salmon freak and it satisfied all my salmon dreams.  I asked for a box shortly after I got my dish, but ended up eating the whole thing and leaving the box--oops!

I was told that the menu will change monthly for now--with the hopes that weekly changes can happen soon. I am excited to see what is added and love the feel of the place!  I will be back, and--you cant beat the location! Right next to Montgomery BART!  Perfect for an East Bay girl like me!
author: Laura P.

description: This is a great location for a business lunch. Smack in the middle of Fidi. The drink menu is pretty extensive and you can tell that they are keeping up with the mixology trends. I was disappointed because the waitress mixed up my order and brought me baked ziti instead of the pappardelle I requested. I'm not a drama queen so I didn't send it back. It was very decadent and pretty delicious. That's a mistake I can handle.
author: Ronita J.

description: What a lovely little find in FiDi. After attending Outside Lands, and wanting to get away to find some civilized eats and high octane beverages, Per Diem was the little gem that delivered. Burrata toast with an interesting spin with honey and almonds, delectable house made pastas....the Berkshire Pork Chop one of the best in the city. Excellent spin on poutine with oxtail gravy. The cheese platter was massive and yummy. The staff is over stretched, but they work hard and aim to please. Will be back!
author: V K.

description: Visited here with my foodie friend JoAnn who always knows what's good. I loved their deep fried oyster po' boy! The oysters were in a light batter and cooked to perfection. Like succulent little dumplings. I'll be back!
author: Paula H.

description:
Per Diem is a nice spot in Fi-Di.  The interior is eclectic and cozy without feeling over-crowded.  It had a modern/trendy speakeasy feel to it.  I went on a Wednesday after work for dinner.  The bar area was nice and filled with the standard Fi-Di crowd (loosened ties, rolled up cuffs, speak of bond rates, etc.).  The rest of the restaurant had a broader cross-section of clientele.

The drink menu was well rounded.  The wine list had some good selection but was not overwhelming.

The menu was small, but there were many good choices and it was sufficient to provide options to most eaters.  The food was good.  I wouldn't say it was overly creative.  The prices were reasonable. 

All-in-all a good experience and a nice place in the area.  Not a top tier restaurant in SF, but certainly a very reliable option.  Easy parking at Stockton/Sutter garage a few blocks away.
author: Randy P.

description:
Like a 3.5 rating.  I went to Per Diem with siblings and friends for a Monday night dinner.  The place was pretty crowded at the bar when I arrived, though it was pretty dead by the time I left around 830 or 9pm.

I thought the menu was fairly limited, but we all found something tasty to order.  Definitely check the menu out before going if you have a dietary restriction.  That being said, the menu we had was slightly different (and had fewer items) than what was online.  I went with the pizzetta with broccolini, pancetta, and roasted tomato sauce.  It looked small but was satisfying and tasty.   

Three people at my table ordered the cioppino, which I tried as well. I was good but I still like the one at Sotto Mare the best.  My brother got the buccatini and liked it too.

The food overall is pretty good but not super memorable.  Would I dine there again?  I probably would, but not until I've checked other places out first.  The location is certainly a plus.
author: Naoko M.

description: Bartenders are super friendly and the cocktails are hella strong! Say hi and be nice to Arne and he'll do you right with his sweet smile and heavy pours!
author: Ayele A.

description:
We had a company lunch and we went here. I ordered Mary's chicken. Got an airline breast, finger potatoes, and asparagus. Chicken was well cooked, moist and flavorful. Had other things at the table. We had Poutine, which I always wanted to try, and liked it.

Others have complained about the atmosphere but, while it wasent quiet, I didn't have an issue -- we could talk and hear people at the other end of the table.
author: Brian C.

description: I've been here several times now, for a happy hour and for lunches and have been pleased as punch every time. I can't seem to stray from the crab cobb salad (with pickled egg!), but the daily soups have also been perfect. Hand-crafted cocktails and careful wine and beer selection, as well as the nautical/found art décor make a it a fun spot to take clients or the S.O.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Came here early evening and was glad we had a reservation. The bar was swarming with people, but once they started to leave the whole place quieted down. 

I see this as a place where you share a bunch of things with friends, even though they do have a couple entrees. We had the burrata, chard and bacon pizza, broccoli rabe and French fries and it was plenty.

Cocktails were delish and divided on the menu into two categories: old money and new money.

I misheard the waiter and thought you could order biscotti cookies for dessert, but it's actually an accompaniment. BUT, he was so kind that he brought one for me anyhow. Good service, atmosphere and food.
author: Tamara M.

description: I have been here for both lunch and dinner. One of my favorite places in the city. The atmosphere, the customer service as well as the quality of the food makes this place really enjoyable. I would surely recommend this place who enjoys small cozy hidden places.
author: Marianna L.

description:
My favorite thing about Per Diem is the atmosphere. It's so alive and bustling (without being too crowded or, god  forbid, trendy.) It feels festive in there.
My boyfriend has tried every Manhattan in the city and likes this one enough to be a regular so I can say with confidence that the cocktails are really good.
The food is really tasty.
If you call ahead to make a reservation request a table by the window. It's the best spot, with lots of light and kind of secluded (kiss someone!)
author: D Z.

description: Came here on a Saturday once and it was their 1-year anniversary. Good crowd, good music, and good food. Came back recently with some out of town friends and they loved it. All the appetizers and pastas were very well done (that bread with cheese and honey is to die for).
author: Z L.

description:
Heads-up to those who have yet to use your Bloomspot 5-course dinner at Per Diem.

We used ours last night and not only did we  experience some of the worst service of all time (after 40 minutes all we had been served was 1/2 strawberry), there was absolutely no way the meal was an $80 5-course meal.  

While it was not clear from the offer, the deal was actually a fixed menu and this is what we were served:

Course 1 -  1/2 strawberry with a tad of feta
Course 2 - Pizza with fig, mozzarella and very little lamb sausage
Course 3 - Teeny (really teeny) arugula salad w/ beans and citrus
Course 4 - Vegetarian Eggplant ratatouille on polenta
Course 5 - Ginger float (disgusting)

This was absolutely NOT an $80 value meal.  It wasn't even a $40 value meal.  Clearly the objective was to fill you up on the cheapest possible items...pizza and polenta....please.

I do want to acknowledge that when we complained about the slow service the manager did apologize, attempted to rush our meal and waived the corkage.  However, that does not make up for the fact that it was an incredibly disappointing dining experience....on all levels.  Given so many great City options I'll be surprised if Per Diem makes it.
author: Sandy S.

description: Jessica is awesome! Must come and have some flat bread and wonderful wine and mix drinks. Love the room.
author: Carmen W.

description:
A new place for happy hour in Financial District! Worth to go!
But lunch quality surprised me, crab sandwich and oyster sandwich were absolutely delicious! and price was acceptable!
author: chaoqiu h.

description: It's definitely a $$$ if you add the beverages, also because the amount of the main entree won't keep you full. The cheese plate is very good. Atmosphere is great with some old touches.
author: Zuck L.

description: I always enjoy coming to Per Diem for lunch and their happy hour is great too. Jessica is always pleasant and very knowledgable about the menu.
author: Leon K.

description:
Got take out.  The Crispy Pork Belly for $12 was not good (in contrast to Claudine French Eatery, which has a fantastic pork belly dish) and the Meatball Gigante for $9 was extremely salty.  The Burrata on a Grilled Crostone for $11 was delicious, though.  It's a thin toasted slice of bread topped with chilled burrata cheese, drizzled with honey, sliced almonds sprinkled on top.  Mmm!

Though I didn't eat in, the restaurant vibe seemed fun and lively.  Focus might be more on the drinks than the quality of the (expensive) food.
author: K L.

description:
Went to Per Diem for lunch, the service is pretty slow. When the food finally came out, I was shocked by the small portion. I ordered Bucatini, the pasta was under-cooked and the sauce was not flavorful at all.
The deco is great, the only thing good about this restaurant.
My waiter over-charged me for my dishes and after correcting it, still charge my tip based on the wrong price.
Per Diem is on my black list now, a definitely no go.
author: Pei H.

description:
Per Diem is a solid addition to the neighborhood.  Shared the prawns and "Burata on a Grilled Crostone" as starters.  Both were excellent and polished off immediately.  The Mary's chicken, the crab melt and the truffle fries were also delicious.  Only the Cioppino was just so-so.

I'll be back very soon.
author: Java Z.

description:
The location is great and I loved the food. I had a risotto the first time and spinach rivoli on my second visit and both were amazing and not too expensive either! Wine was great but a little pricy. 
For an Italian orientated restaurant I was surprised that they did not have espresso. They only served Americano and that coffee really was not very good. 
However, their cheese platter and desserts are great and the staff is really wonderful so I can definitely recommend this place!
author: K S.

description:
I give Per Diem three stars as a possible happy hour location in the financial district, not dinner.  For dinner it is two stars.

We went in for an early dinner last Friday night.  The bar area was packed, which created a fun vibe.  That said, this is probably a better place for just drinks and a pizzetta.  Or lunch.  

They had a limited menu and it might have changed in a week.  We shared a burata crostone and a pizzetta.  I had the brisket sandwich, which sounded better than it was.  I would not order it again.  My husband got the truffle egg sandwich.  He was disappointed because the wheat bread it came on was really hard.  he ended up having to eat it open face with a fork.  The star of the table was the grilled crab sandwich.  The bread was slathered in butter and grilled to golden brown.  I would go back for lunch to get that sandwich on a day on which I felt particularly decadent.  

The red wine was served warm.

After we had apparently sat for too long, the manager came over and asked, "did you enjoy your dinner?"  We said yes.  He then invited us to leave so "other people can enjoy dinner, too."  I absolutely understand that restaurants need to turn tables, but this could have been communicated a little better, we thought.  Unfortunately, it left a little bit of a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Amber B.

description: This place is so cozy! I love coming here every time I'm in town. The food is always delicious and the staff are friendly. Loved the burrata crostini with honey and almonds on my most recent visit. Great place for a date or to catch up with friends. Quiet enough for a good conversation, but still trendy and lively at the same time.
author: Nicole B.

description:
I often find dinner places in the FiDi to be overpriced for the quality (due to all the business meals and tourists). However, Per Diem's pizzas and pastas about reasonable (~$9 - $14 each). I strongly recommend the homemade pastas. The best appetizer is Burata, though it seems a little expensive for what you get.

Decor and vibe is one of the best aspects. It's a nice restaurant, but casual attire is completely acceptable. Keep your eyes out for the dart board posted too high on the wall...
author: Katherine C.

description:
A bit disapointing.  But first the back story.  My date had some dietary restrictions, e.g. no pork, so our selections were a bit limited.  That said I will be going back to try those interesting dishes that I could not try this time.

First, the oysters were fresh and delicious, but our second appatizer was the burrata on Grilled Crostone; virtually tasteless except for the honey. 

For the entrees, my date asked for a salad with off-menu request for chicken which was accomdated.  That was good, but it exposed the limited menu, but that was complicated by her dietary restrictions obviously.  Not Per Diem's fault there.  

I had the rabbit, which though some pieces were overcooked, those parts that weren't were quite good. 

The decor was fantastic, but the service was not that great; we had some problems with the waiter apparently disappearing and there was a big gap between getting a second glass of wine and the appearance of the first appetizer.  More attentive service could have brought the sale of another glass of cab.

The dessert, a delicious chocolate cake, was great.  So a good finish to the meal.

So, basically I will try it again.  Even for the rabbit, but also for the mussels, roasted pork and other items that caught my eye.
author: J H.

description: Great times had by all!  Food was great, service was good and the decor was amazing.  Perfect place for happy hour, or a late night dinner.
author: Marnie K.

description: Came here for dinner on a Friday night and boy is it gorgeous to look at!  The area needs more places for dinner, so it is a good addition.  Having said that, it still need some work.  My appetizer (cheese plate) was very good and my main dish (risotto) was also good.  Unfortunately, though my husband liked his green tomato panzanella, he found the tagliatelle really lacking -- so garlicky he could barely taste any of the other ingredients.  No bread offered during the meal, which, as he said, might have helped with the garlic assault.  The service was also less than perfect -- very friendly waitstaff, but my cheese plate came, I finished it, and THEN my husband's salad arrived.  We did not want to share the dishes, and they really should have asked if they thought that was what we had planned.  A little more polish might be good -- not sure if everyone wants to see the servers dancing to the music in the corner while you wait to order a glass of wine...  Hope it improves -- love the location and the cozy interior.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Went here for the first time last Friday and will definitely be coming back. Our waitress was excellent and so was the food. We had the Ciopinno, Bucatini and Caesar salad - all were excellent! It was a little pricey given the portion size but the quality of the food was definitely worth the money. 

I would also recommend making a reservation because the space isn't huge and probably fills up quickly on weekends.
author: Lauren S.

description: Great atmosphere, love the shelves of books. At Per Diem the pasta is cooked well and the wine is tasty. Service is nice, but the restaurant is understaffed so you might not get the attention you desire.   For a downtown SF restaurant serving Italian its a good bet.
author: Brianna M.

description: I went here for dinner with my grandparents. The noise level wasn't too bad for a bar/ restaurant, which is important since my grandfather uses a hearing aid. The service was just okay- we had to flag down the waitress a few times. The food was good- we got a few apps to share and the highlight was the poutine. I'll probably meet up with friends who also work in the fidi here if we're too lazy to find somewhere more adventurous to eat.
author: Brooke G.

description:
I work across the street so I'll be back and am rooting for this place. But after my first lunch visit, I'd suggest to the wait staff to not pitch the "bacon and eggs" sandwich as the chef's signature dish like mine did. It's nothing special at best, and actually hard to eat since the crumbly bread and egg salad fall apart as you try to chew though the thick, tough bacon. No real special flavor to speak up, so basically it is just a poorly-crafted gimmick. 

Keep pushing the burrata crostini though. That was really tasty. And despite the hiccups in menu and process which seems to come with most SF openings these days, the staff is really working hard to make it a good experience.
author: Jeff T.

description: Had the dungeness crab melt sandwich & a side of fries for lunch. The crab melt is combined with this gooey white cheddar and dried tomatoes. The bread is a sourdough variety and is smeared with lots of aioli (a little too much for me). The sammie was tasty and certainly rich. It got eventually soggy from the aioli/cheese mixture. Solid but pricey though. The fries were just terrific...can't say no to dat. The other menu items look good. The place has a nice crowd. The service was average.
author: Derek N.

description: Had lunch for the first time here. Definitely enjoyed the menu variety and appetizers, especially the meatball... very tasty.
author: Marky M.

description:
I like Per Diem because it can accommodate reservations for larger lunch groups of 7 to 8 without much fuss. Somehow, its interior decorating works - a bit mish mashed, but it's a nice backdrop for conversations.  I really like the burrata on bread with honey and almonds plus I always appreciate when I can find Fevertree Bitter Lemon Tonic.  What I haven't really liked in my visits is the other food so while this is a good lunch spot to chat and have a drink, alcoholic or not, and share an appetizer, I still have not found a good entree.

The Oyster Po' Boy didn't mix well with the spicy pickled toppings.  The minestrone soup was chopped up vegetables in a light broth and tasted sour, something that one of my dining mates agreed on.  I tried someone's cream of asparagus soup which was okay.  The bucatini was all right, but wasn't something I would hanker to reorder.

All in all, a return place for the ease of fitting in larger groups, but not at the top of my list if I want a good lunch one-on-one with a friend.  I might try the Prince Edward Island mussels next time.  The table next to us got them and it looked good enough to bump the PEI specialty up my list for this place.  :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Overall great experience. 

The first time I attempted to come here (without a reservation) the wait was 1.5 hours, so I left & made a note to come back. Flash-forward a few weeks later & I made a reservation on open table the day of, on a Friday, no problem, plenty of open slots available.

The food was delicious. We started out with the local west coast oysters, very good. I have seen some mentions of them being on the smaller side, which they are, but the quality is there. I had the cioppino with a nice buttery Chardonnay & my boyfriend had the special which was a corned pork (St. Patrick's Day) with a Guinness. All very satisfying on a cold rainy day. We did not have dessert, so cannot vouch for that. 

Our waiter was attentive & nice.  I enjoy sitting a nice, welcoming place with a great vibe & ambiance, this fits the bill. 

In my opinion, the food/drinks are priced fairly for the quality, service & location of the restaurant.
author: Lily R.

description: I've been to Per Diem twice, once for lunch and once for dinner.  Both times I enjoyed good food, attentive service and charming decor.  I also think the prices are more reasonable than the average FiDi hotspot.
author: Ariana L.

description: Lovely atmosphere. Good service. Sadly, they've taken a free hand with the salt - in every dish.
author: Joshua M.

description: Great mussels, interesting bone marrow appetizer (just meh, not great), and a good pear and cava cocktail. I would go again, definitely delicious - even if the atmosphere is a tad bit snooty.
author: Jessie W.

description:
I made my second trip to Per Diem this week and it did not disappoint.  I tried different dishes on each visit and every one of them was fantastic.  

Don't miss out on the amazing burrata and make sure to ask what the specials are!
author: Amanda P.

description: I'm in love with this place in more ways than one! The happy hour is always hopping and the beer list is really fantastic. The bucatini is my go-to dish -- the pasta is homemade and the pork ragu is just the right kind of spicy. The burrata is not to be missed!
author: Shelley R.

description:
Great afternoon for lunch. Pasta was superb and the service was fantastic. My lunch partner and I lamented how the enthusiasm shared by JP and Chris was the kind that you can't pay for. These guys were fun, engaging and above all awesome hosts. 

There are some kinks in the operations- like some dishes weren't available and hiccup here or there- but don't get yourself into a knot over it. The atmosphere is chill, the food is good and service more than makes up for it. Try this place out now while they are still young so years from now you can boast about how you were coming here since the beginning and how it's gotten too popular. 

Bring your clients, bring a date or leave your number for the cute waitress.
author: jason h.

description: The design of the restaurant is great, and the service was fine, but the food was lacking.  Three entrees and one dessert were not available to order from a menu that has limited choices to begin with.  The risotto was visually a dud; it just looked like a pile of rice.  The flavor was fine, but it just tasted like rice and cheese.   There was nothing in it.  The cioppino suffered from a thick sauce.  The duck was served on minced mirepoix with some delicious bok choy and snap peas, but the duck itself was terribly overcooked and had a blob of apricot jam plopped unceremoniously on top.
author: M H.

description:
After watching the restaurant get ready to open for months, lunch today was my first opportunity to stop in.   On a warm day you'll want to get a seat downstairs...the heat up there was the only reason for the missing star.  They really need to get at least ceiling fans up there.

Pleasant staff (at risk of making an inappropriate comment, the light brown eyes of the hostess are, on their own, worth the trip ).  We were at no point hurried, and, unless you are in a rush, the waitstaff and servers seem to show up at just the right time, despite a full house at the noon hour.  

Portions were just right for a lunch in the financial district.  Both of us had the lasagna of the day.  Very good, and leaning towards light and dry, as opposed to heavy and greasy.  Make your own Arnold Palmer with bottled darjeeling tea and lemonade in small carafes were a fun tableside project. 

I love finding a new, pleasant, interesting and tasty spot for lunch within a block or so.  This is one.
author: Derek T.

description:
Grabbed dinner here last week based upon all the hoopla of a new restaurant in the Fi-Di area. So far most people seem to have reviewed lunch and happy hour, so here's a dinner review:

Food - Pretty decent. Tried the broccolini pizza, PEI mussels, and Buccatini pasta. Nothing super special in my opinion but everything was fresh and nicely presented.

Ambiance - Nice, but not great for conversation. The dining areas are integrated with the bar, so it's hard to have an intimate engagement. 

Service - Not impressed. Waiter kept forgetting about us, couldn't hear anything we were saying, and didn't really do much to make me feel like we were important to him (even with few tables). 

Drink service looked great at the bar, so I'll definitely go again to check that out, but for dinner...there are far better choices to explore in my opinion.
author: Timothy H.

description: Went with friends last night. The Bucatini was great! Perfect sauce, neither sweet nor sour. The Burata toast was good.  The décor was unique and neat.
author: Gopi M.

description: Went here for a friend's birthday HH.  Didn't have anything to eat, though the food that went past me looked pretty tasty.  The cocktails are where it's at.  When I asked for a Manhattan, the bartender, Joe, proceeded to ask me in which style I'd like it made.  I've gotten so used to bartender's not knowing what a Perfect Manhattan is, that I simply don't ask anymore, so Joe's inquiry was quite refreshing.  It was made according to its name, and I was delighted.
author: Chelsea A.

description: This is one of my favorite spots in the Financial District to take a visitor out for lunch. Per Diem has an awesome atmosphere like the inside of a wooden ship, fast and attentive service, and the food is consistently delicious. I'm a big fan of the bucatini pasta (thin round noodles with meat sauce).
author: Stephanie P.

description: Came here for an happy hour and the service was horrible. The bar was completely packed and everyone was standing around waiting for a drink. I stood there and looked around while there was 1 bartender working and 1 person cutting fruit in the middle of the busiest time of the night. You would've figured they would've gotten there prep work ahead of time instead of during service. After standing there for 10 mins along with a few others, we left and went to rickhouse where they actually know how to run a successful bar.  I can understand they may have good food but there happy hour/bar needs work.
author: Vince W.

description: Great food and environment!  Lots of options for different types of diets- I can't wait to go back!
author: Crystal M.

description: Went here for a business meeting and it looked super cute initially.  I ordered the Oyster Po'boy and was extremely disappointed.  The oysters were deep fried and almost flavorless. The side salad, on the other hand, was pretty good.  Ingredients tasted fresh and food was delivered pretty quickly.  Overall, I had a pretty neutral experience dining here.   I probably wouldn't come back unless my company is paying for my lunch again lol
author: Anna G.

description: Great atmosphere and ambiance. Perfect for a date, kind of speak easy type. Though not a lot of options for vegetarians.
author: Rajat S.

description: per diem is a quite the gem in the financial district. ambiance is great, service is awesome, and the food never fails to amaze me. if you are ever in town i highly recommend you stop by per diem and grab something to eat especially with bree!! she is always welcoming, very knowledgeable and attentive with her guests. keep on doing what you're doing!
author: Hannah B.

description: Expensive, has a good arraignment of food options.  however overall the food was only ok based on even if was a lower price.  Nothing was horrible, but nothing and I mean nothing stood out.
author: Dylan B.

description: Quaint place with cute lighting. Happy hour was pretty hard to find parking, I got stuck on Bush and ended up walking a few blocks but cute cute place. Love the bubbly drink they make! :) YUM!
author: K T.

description:
Just had lunch with co-workers for my birthday.  Started off rough, didn't have a beer someone ordered (it was on the menu, but they were out of it), didn't have any more burger  (had run out) ........ Menu was interesting, food seemed fresh, but service was not great.  Some of us ordered a salad or soup plus an entree, all the food was brought out at the same time, no concept of "courses" and the servers had  no idea who had ordered what. My lasagnette was only luke warm...... After plates were cleared, we had to request dessert menus and asked for coffee only to be told they were out of coffee.  How does a restaurant run out of coffee?  Clearly there is a provisioning problem.

Lovely space, hope they can up their game,  train their staff  in the basics and figure out ordering of  beer, burgers and coffee.
author: Joyce S.

description: I reallllly wanted to like Per Diem, especially since it's on my way home and would make for a great HH spot. But I was pretty disappointed with the experience overall. There wasn't much space at the bar so the host directed us up to the dining area (even though we told him we weren't planning to order dinner) and we ended up with the rudest waitress! She made it quite clear that she didn't appreciate our lack of a dinner order and took every opportunity to push/make faces when she came over. Frankly, it got to the point where I was actually enjoying making snarky comments back at her so we didn't get up and when we should have. The apps we got weren't all that special either (cheese plate and mushroom flatbread) - there are so many better places in the area - don't waste your time!
author: Maya S.

description:
Per Diem is my kind of place. It's charming with French-inspired decor, intimate and has delightful food. 

Upon entering, it's like walking into a French cafe in the middle of Paris. The restaurant is narrow with dark wooden beams and blues in the decor. There are small tables all around and a small bar that lines up to the kitchen. They also have a staircase leading you to more seating. It's an adorable restaurant, especially for a "ladies who lunch" kind of day. 

The menu has several options and most likely something for everyone. They have the typical soups and salads as well as a variety of pizzas. In addition, they have a decent sized list of sandwiches as well. I shared a crab melt as well as a ham and brie so I was able to try both. Don't be fooled by the dull description of the ham and brie sandwich. I must admit that I wasn't sold by the sandwich when reading the description on the menu. Ham and brie on sourdough? That seems like a very boring option. However, the sandwich is anything but dull. It's actually delicious and one of the better sandwiches I've eaten in awhile! Yes there is ham and brie, but the ham is warm and freshly sliced, the brie is creamy and the sandwich is topped with sweet onions (I think they were onions at least) as well as a sweet mustard. The bread is perfectly soft and it truly melts in your mouth. I will find myself thinking about this sandwich after I leave the city. I definitely liked the ham and brie more than the crab melt and going into it, I thought I would think the opposite. The crab melt was a little too mayo-happy. It was good but after biting into the ham and brie, it just wasn't giving me the happiness the ham and brie did. 

This restaurant is right up my alley and I will definitely keep it on the map for visits to SF, especially when it's time for a Mom/Daughter lunch or catch-up lunch with girlfriends!
author: Lindsey D.

description:
I'd heard of Per Diem from a resource who has really good taste in food, so I knew I needed to try it. I also looked on Yelp and the pictures made it look like an interesting choice visually. 
Both my friend and I really enjoyed dining here. It was a rainy, cold Wednesday night, so we were both happy to be inside a nice, inviting restaurant. Since I had just worked out, I was in the mood for something super cheesy and a refreshing glass of pinot grigio. 
For starters we shared Burata on a Grilled Crostone. It was soo good, we each felt we could have had one all to ourselves. 
Next I got the Panzenela with Bloomsdale Spinach salad and the Truffle and Tomato Brisket Lasagnetta. Both were really tasty. The Lasagnetta was super rich, and comforting.
Lastly we shared a dessert...something with pear and ice cream? Really good, whatever it was called. 
Our waitress was super friendly and prompt with our orders. The layout of the restaurant was also nice and user friendly (aka bathroom both upstairs and downstairs haha). We also liked the old school type of look and feel. 
Now I can see why my foodie friend likes this place so much!
author: Sonya D.

description:
Crostini? burnt. Salad? a flavorless jungle.  Gnocchi? overlooked. Filet? cooked well done when ordered med rare. scallops? undercooked.  worst meal I have ever
had on NYE.  

since they just opened this month,  I will give them another try on 6 months
author: Christian K.

description: Ok, so my emails were being directed into their spam folder and I just received a $50 gift certificate as an apology. They are back in my good graces again.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
For the dishes, they serve good ones. The size of the food was a bit small but I liked the tastes of all dishes we ordered. 

The issue made me to give 3 stars out of 5 was the stairs to the second floor and the services.

The stairs is over the bar counter and you can see through it. How do I know? I wore a skirt and while I was looking down as walking up, I could see a guy below the stair looking up on me (or the bottom of me). It was embarrassing. I wanted to yell at him what he is looking up at but couldn't.

The attendance was poor. It's an Italian restaurant but no bread before the meal. Even though we asked some extra bread for one of dishes, the waitress couldn't  bring any (she apologized it with free dessert wine at the end of the meal though). 

Anyway, food itself was great and worth to try.
author: Rachael C.

description: Really good - nice wine selection, good service.  We tried the asparagus soup, cheese plate, spinach salad, shrimp cocktail and the kale and caramelized onion pizza.  My friend felt the pizza was too salty, but loves this place.
author: Jaime O.

description:
I went here on a Monday night for a business dinner with 5 other coworkers. We were seated upstairs, which was great because I could actually talk to my coworkers without yelling. We were seated right next to a little atrium, which gave the table location a nice atmosphere. 

Usually I only order an entree if I go out with friends, but for some reason business dinners always include much more food (oof). I started out with a glass of pinot noir. When it arrived I wondered where the rest of my wine had gone. Their wine portions are very skimpy. For $12, I expect my glass to be more than half full. I had a shrimp cocktail for my appetizer. That was good and the shrimp was fresh. My portion included 6 shrimp, which was totally acceptable. For my entree I had their swordfish special. The fish was delicious. It was served over kale and a carrot puree (I omitted the rice). The kale could have been cooked better. Some of it was nicely crisp but other pieces were chewy. Dessert was a chocolate roulade, which was a like an uptown version of a Hostess Ho Ho, but that hit the spot. It would have been better with some sort of creme fraiche addition to make it a little creamier. 

I have to agree with some of the other posts that service is slow. Our waitress was pretty attentive and our water glasses were filled often, but the time between courses as well as just getting the appetizers started was slower than it should have been. I don't like being rushed during dinner, but the wait time was just too long, and I can't see why given the fact that it was a Monday night and we had early reservations (6 pm) before the crowds started arriving. 

All in all a solid meal, with room for improvement in timing.
author: Lori M.

description:
My boyfriend and I visited Per Diem for the first time a couple of Fridays ago. I made my reservation on OpenTable and indicated that I needed a wheelchair-accessible table.

THANK YOU so much for accommodating us! I was very impressed with the hostess' service and had one of the few tables on the ground floor reserved for us as our intended table was occupied. She gave us a choice to wait or take the backup table and move to the other one later. I have never experienced such a great host!

The wait service and food were superb also! I had never heard of Per Diem before finding them on OpenTable and was very pleasantly surprised by everything. The food was perfect, and I get hungry just thinking about it. We enjoyed everything so much and are looking forward to returning again. 

I definitely recommend the bucatini with spicy pork ragu. My boyfriend had a daily special which were wonderful raviolis with some rabbit.  Both were well worth the price!

Please keep up the good work!
author: Kelley P.

description: 2 stars for the ambiance/decor, but everything else was mediocre to downright nasty. They managed to give me bland Osso Bucco - not sure how that is possible. I mean even the meager amount of marrow in their too small bone was bland. And they served me burnt bread. WTF? Don't bother.
author: Jay N.

description: I love the dungeness crab sandwich, the cioppino, the BURRATA appetizer (seriously like the best cheese ever - its mozzarella plus cream and there is NOTHING wrong with that!) and the brocollini lemon almond side. So, um, pretty much everything I've ever had there. The decor has been carefully done and creates a warm cozy ambiance in what could be a very industrial space. I've only ever sat upstairs and they have a super cute little patio area that my colleagues and I often have happy hour on. Amazing drinks, attentive service - what more could you ask for in a reasonably priced sit down restaurant in the FiDi? Nothing.
author: Brenda K.

description: Came here for happy hour and appetizers. Cheese plate and flatbread pizza was delicious. Great spot for a drink after work!
author: Mike G.

description:
Good food, but nothing special. It's a "safe" restaurant to bring non-adventurous eaters for a nicer meal.

I liked my papparadelle and loved the burrata on crostone, but didn't think the latter was worth $11 for a little cheese on one slice of bread.

Service was nice, but reeeeaaalllly slow. And we didn't realize they served complimentary bread until it was brought out after we were almost done with our entrees. (By that time, what's the point of bringing it out at all?)
author: D E.

description: Reserved dining upstairs for our son's and NEW daughter-in-law's after City Hall wedding reception.  Got there about 20 minutes early and were told they were preparing the upstairs dining area for us.  No problem, and we were escorted upstairs after about 10 minutes.  We occupied the entire upstairs which also features a bar.  Our server, Kalisa, was fantastic!  She  was attentive to who order what drinks and came by repeatedly to check on everyone.  Per Diem also personalized the menus for this occasion.  Each table was served flatbread w/ arugula for appetizers.  This was really good!  The menu consisted of:  French Onion Soup or Sonoma Garden salad.  Entrees offered: Roasted chicken, Croque Madame, and Tri Tip.  ALL were great!  For dessert we had a triple layered chocolate mousse.  If there weren't any guests sitting near me I would have licked my plate.  This was my first time here and my wife and I talked about it on the drive home.  We're going to make plans to dine there again......soon!   Noise level downstairs is pretty loud but you would expect that.  Upstairs was quiet, as you didn't have to talk loud for someone to hear you.
author: Brian W.
